headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Avery Dennison's earnings conference call for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 2, 2010. This call is being recorded, and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today through midnight Pacific
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Avery Dennison's earnings conference call for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 2, 2010. This call is being recorded, and will be available for replay from 1:00 p.m. Pacific time today through midnight Pacific time February 3, 2010. To access the replay, Please dial 1-800-633-8284, or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21438865. I would now like to turn the call over to Eric Leeds, Avery Dennison's Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Fourth Quarter 2009 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K, an
componenttext: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Fourth Quarter 2009 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K, and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com.  We remind you that these results are preliminary, as we have not yet filed our 10-Q. Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes interest expense, restructuring and other charges included in the other expense line of our P&L. Also referenced are transition costs associated with acquisition integrations. Restructuring charges and integration transition costs tend to be fairly discreet in amount, frequency and timing. In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus on margin commentary on pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. This detail is in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release. We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we've provided today, along with our 2008 Form 10-K address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations. On the call today are Dean Scarborough, President and CEO; Dan O'Bryant, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Mitch Butier, Corporate Vice President, Global Finance. I'll now turn the call over to Dean, who's participating remotely.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. While 2009 was really a tale of two halves, the first half of the year unprecedented 3 a steep drop in our revenues and very difficult earnings trajectory, followed by a much improved second half of the year. And I'd like to just thank all o
componenttext: Thanks, Eric. While 2009 was really a tale of two halves, the first half of the year unprecedented 3 a steep drop in our revenues and very difficult earnings trajectory, followed by a much improved second half of the year. And I'd like to just thank all of our employees for an exceptional performance in probably one of the most difficult economic environments we faced in a number of years. We ended the year with record free cash flow, over $450 million. It enabled us to reduce debt by $300 million in the second half, while still continuing to invest in new markets and emerging growth opportunities. And we made great progress to our end of 2000 debt reduction target of at least $350 million. Now we had a major effort last year on reducing our fixed cost, and Dan will go through some of the details on our restructuring program, which is still undergoing and will likely conclude in the second quarter of this year. We made strong productivity gains. In fact, operational working capital as a percentage of sales was at its best level in over four years. Our second-half inventory turns were at their highest level in three years, and we saw solid margin improvement in the second half over the first half, with the fourth quarter gross margins 2.3 points higher than the fourth quarter of last year. And it's really all about our ability to raise and maintain prices to reduce costs, including both raw material and our fixed cost of operations. Now in the fourth quarter, our operating margins were a bit lower than we expected, really for two reasons. One was we lowered our inventories by a very aggressive amount, which caused us to take some fixed cost charges on the P&L. And then last year, we were reversing bonus accruals because we we're missing our targets for the year. And because of it, the great achievement on free cash flow, there was quite a difference in the year-over-year swing in bonus accruals.Now I'll talk a little bit about what's going in and the businesses. The pressure-sensitive sector, great discipline on price and productivity all year. Organic sales were up by 2% in the fourth quarter, so we've lapped the declines finally. And emerging markets really came back strong. And specifically, China was up more than 20% in the quarter. And they continued to go, really just gangbusters in the second half. In Retail Information Services, our fourth quarter sales decline was the lowest of the year. You'll recall that we really started to see a steep drop in the back half of 2008. We've seen retailers now begin to maintain their unprecedented low inventories. And so the inventory sales ratio, which improved all year, looks like it's reached the bottom. And I really don't think it'll be until the spring season until we see that opportunity for real large top-line improvement. As you recall, that business is quite seasonal, so we don't really start to see those results until very late in the first quarter and in the second quarter. And we continue to take fixed cost out of the business with our aggressive restructuring programs.Office product sales did decline. White-collar unemployment is still pretty high, and purchasing on the corporate side is still down. And we had a bit of a fall-off in the fourth quarter from a very strong back-to-school in the third. But even in this tough environment, we invested in some new marketing programs, in new products, which we launched in the fourth quarter. And we took a little bit of market share during the quarter as well, so we're feeling more confident about that business.So we're well positioned as markets recover. We have the leading share in our core businesses, very strong operating leverage, really solid variable margins, and we're managing that price inflation GAAP in raw material costs out and focused discipline employees. So let me tell you what we're thinking about 2010. I do expect a better year. I guess, it would be hard not to. And the major factor that will impact our results is still the strength and length of the recovering. And frankly, our mindset is anticipating a moderate recovery, as the impact of inventory destocking is over.  And we're going to be relying mainly on consumer demand. It's not clear to me that people will start to restock inventories very rapidly. But we'll continue to strengthen our financial position and also step up our investment in growth, especially in the areas of marketing, where we're adding capability to do end-use marketing to accelerate the rate of decoration transfer in raw materials and pressure-sensitive. We see a lot of new growth opportunities in RFID. More people are looking at item-level marketing today than ever before. And I really sense that retailers are interested in better control of inventories in the store as well as the ability to control labor class. And I mentioned before, we've invested in new products and accelerated our new product development process in our Office Products business. So now I'll turn it over to Dan.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. I'm not going to walk through the slides page by page this quarter, and see if we can leave a little more room for Q&A. But I will hit a few of the highlights across the business and each of our business segments. So first off, sales in the
componenttext: Thanks, Dean. I'm not going to walk through the slides page by page this quarter, and see if we can leave a little more room for Q&A. But I will hit a few of the highlights across the business and each of our business segments. So first off, sales in the fourth quarter, as you can see were down organically about 1%, which was a continued improvement from the rate of the first three quarters. And don't forget that the effect of having added a 53rd week in the year was to move the full holiday period into the fourth quarter, which reduced sales by an estimated 3%. Taking that into account, the U.S. and Europe are both improving, but still operating below prior year. Of these, the Asia really surged ahead. We had the best growth year in China in several years.The operating margin declined a bit, mostly due to higher MG&A expenses in the quarter, which I'll walk you through it in a moment. Gross profit margins remained well ahead of prior year, with a continuing positive impact of restructuring and productivity, as well as the positive impact of our year-on-year pricing in raw material results. But sequentially, we saw some margin decline, both fixed cost leverage contributed as well as segment mix. Margins were also impacted by the significant inventory reduction that we had in the fourth quarter. And in addition, Office Product sales in the fourth quarter were lower as a percentage of sales with our higher margins. That impacted us as well.The MG&A costs were higher in the quarter primarily due to two or three factors. One, the currency translation impact to the numbers by about $10 million. And after a period of relative austerity associated with the decline in economy, in the fourth quarter we increase investment in marketing and business development. And we incurred a higher employee cost, including bonus accruals which I'll comment a little bit further as we go.As we look at MG&A levels going forward, we project MG&A to be higher than it was in the third quarter but lower than in the fourth quarter because of a number of items that uniquely impacted the fourth. This level of spending also provides for some room for us to make additional marketing expenses as the year goes by, which Dean addressed.The bonus accruals changed from reversals last year, which benefited fourth quarter '08 results to accruals in the fourth quarter of '09. And the 4Q '09 accruals impacted both cost of goods sold and the MG&A to the tune of about $25 million on a combined basis. The primary driver of the year-on-year change was the extremely strong cash flow results that we had, which we're very proud of.  It's been a year where we started the year going into difficult economic circumstances, and moved much of the focus of the organization and our bonus pools toward the free cash flow objective and we achieved well beyond expectation there. We reduced debt by $300 million in the second half of the year. We managed to maintain good liquidity throughout the economic crisis. We protected our credit ratings and access to commercial paper, which benefited us throughout the year and kept our cost of debt down materially.And working capital contributed about $200 million. I'm talking about operating working capital. That part which is managed by our divisions contributed about $200 million of free cash flow. And 80% of that was productivity on the working capital lines, so we're very pleased with what we've been able to do on the free cash flow.Our current restructuring program will conclude on schedule at the end of the second quarter. And we've expanded the program a bit to an annual run rate savings of $180 million by mid-2010. We achieved 75% of that run rate by the end of 2009. So the total cost of the program will now be approximately $160 million, about 70% of which are cash costs. 2009 free cash flow included about $70 million of the cash costs with this program. And most of that, the balance will hit in 2010.So let me just give a little bit of color on our business units, starting with Pressure-sensitive Materials. Sales grew about 2% due to strength in the emerging markets. The rate of decline in most regions has improved, but is still in the negative territory. Asia was a big driver with China, as I said, is best-rated in several years, north of the 20% mark. And recovery in North America and Europe remains muted.Operating margin increased year-over-year due to the progress we've made on both productivity and pricing, along with raw material costs. And while we are maintaining most of the benefits of these factors, we're feeling some inflation now and we are adjusting prices. Sequential margins are down due to the employee cost that we've talked about and to the early signs of inflation hitting some of our raw materials. In Retail Information Services, sales were off about 2% in the fourth quarter. And while it's still negative, that's the lowest decline that we've seen all year. Revenue lift in this business is key to the margin improvement that we anticipate. The business continues to take out fixed costs to streamline its operations, and are launching new products and services as well. So we continue to target double-digit margins as retail markets begin to improve.In Office and Consumer Products, sales declined more significantly, reflecting continued weakened market demand, led by slower corporate purchasing activity consistent with the white-collar unemployment levels that we've seen. We've seen some sequential improvement in the point-of-sales trends in the commercial segment here, but it's still really weak. The fourth quarter commercial point of sale was down 9% versus being down in the low- to mid-teens in each of the first three quarters of 2009. So operating margin declined as we felt the impact of reduced fixed cost, leverage and employee costs.  Office Products did a great job on the cash flow front in the quarter, as did most of our businesses. We also increased marketing and product development spend and launched a few new products has Dean talked about in that part of the business.Now let me shift the focus to Slides 15, 16 and 17, which turns our discussion to 2010 outlook. On 15, we've already talked about the record free cash flow in 2009. The chart in the upper-right corner of that slide shows the decline over the last couple of years in capital spending. We expect capital spending in 2010 of between $125 million and $150 million, which would still be relatively low compared to depreciation and amortization. The lower chart shows the significant productivity we've delivered in operating working capital through 2010, and since the Paxar acquisition, where you see the number peaking in the second quarter of 2007. On Slides 16 and 17, as we did last year, we're listing what we currently believe to be some of the contributing factors to 2010's year-on-year changes in the P&L and in free cash flow. We're again giving 2010 EPS and free cash flow scenarios pegged [ph] off a relatively wide range of revenue assumptions. Where appropriate, we'll update the contributing factors in our 2010 quarterly reports. The key point that we're trying to make on these slides is that it's still difficult to predict revenue and as a result, difficult to predict earnings. But we still expect that free cash flow will be very strong once again in 2010. So that wraps up my brief overview of the slides. We hope you've had a chance to take a look at the rest of that material, and we'd be happy now to take you're questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, I wanted to go back to Slide 16, maybe start with more of a nitty-gritty question. Can you elaborate on the first bullet point, how that should work into our models for the course of the year, both in terms of what you were saying for the first quart
componenttext: Dan, I wanted to go back to Slide 16, maybe start with more of a nitty-gritty question. Can you elaborate on the first bullet point, how that should work into our models for the course of the year, both in terms of what you were saying for the first quarter and for all of 2010?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's s a technical detail, but a relevant particularly in the quarter. The 53rd week that we added was added way back in Q1, but it pushed the rest of the year forward, obviously. And that meant that this year's Q4 had more impact from the holiday se
componenttext: Yes, it's s a technical detail, but a relevant particularly in the quarter. The 53rd week that we added was added way back in Q1, but it pushed the rest of the year forward, obviously. And that meant that this year's Q4 had more impact from the holiday season than we normally would have expected and I think we cut last year, on the 26th of December something, so we had that extra week. So it's purely an estimate, it doesn't impact everything globally, but it looks like to us it was a little over 3% impact on sales, and it has a negative impact on margins in the fourth quarter as well. When we get into the following year, that comparison won't be relevant anymore to us, because we'll be starting obviously the year fully engaged in January. So this should be the final time we have to talk about that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Does it make for perhaps a year-on-year stronger comparison in the first quarter of '10 versus last year?
componenttext: Does it make for perhaps a year-on-year stronger comparison in the first quarter of '10 versus last year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The first quarter of '10 versus last year will make it a little bit weaker on the top line, because it's not one less week of sales but it was that soft week that it lost. But on the bottom line, it would have a negligible impact.
componenttext: The first quarter of '10 versus last year will make it a little bit weaker on the top line, because it's not one less week of sales but it was that soft week that it lost. But on the bottom line, it would have a negligible impact.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In Office Products, obviously there are understandable reasons why the business has been up again, down again. But the performance that you saw on the fourth quarter, does it suggest at all that maybe the business is taking a secular downshift that we nee
componenttext: In Office Products, obviously there are understandable reasons why the business has been up again, down again. But the performance that you saw on the fourth quarter, does it suggest at all that maybe the business is taking a secular downshift that we need to be aware of, or was it purely in your view, a cyclical phenomenon with white collar and corporate purchasing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, George, there are secular headwinds in the businesses that have been ongoing. And first-class mailing is a big application category for us, and that's continuing. The major impact though, is white-collar employment and an inventory destocking. I thi
componenttext: Well, George, there are secular headwinds in the businesses that have been ongoing. And first-class mailing is a big application category for us, and that's continuing. The major impact though, is white-collar employment and an inventory destocking. I think the inventory destocking is pretty much done so now, given where white-collar unemployment is, I think it's going to take a while for us to see a change in that trajectory. And I don't think it's going to come back fast.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like a major change in the fourth quarter with the destock effect. Obviously, we've been going through white-collar employment reductions for a while now. Would that be a fair characterization?
componenttext: So it sounds like a major change in the fourth quarter with the destock effect. Obviously, we've been going through white-collar employment reductions for a while now. Would that be a fair characterization?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Here is the way I would look at it. So destocking's probably not that right term. A lot of times, our customers at the end of the year to true up programs and inventories ordered a little bit more. Sometimes we have -- I think last year with the price inc
componenttext: Here is the way I would look at it. So destocking's probably not that right term. A lot of times, our customers at the end of the year to true up programs and inventories ordered a little bit more. Sometimes we have -- I think last year with the price increase going in, so there was some early buying. There was none of those kind of factors this year and frankly, nobody is buying early to get a bigger rebate, or do any of those kinds of things. That I think is finally flushed out of the system, so we're looking at more normal demand levels.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Presumably though, that might help the first quarter, at least, for the Office Products businesses. If you don't have the same level of borrowing from the future period to the current period to get a rebate, would that be fair?
componenttext: Presumably though, that might help the first quarter, at least, for the Office Products businesses. If you don't have the same level of borrowing from the future period to the current period to get a rebate, would that be fair?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that should.
componenttext: Yes, that should.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, you're coming off the bottom, you saw progress in the second half of 2009. Obviously, demand is not where you ultimately would like it to be. I guess the question is, at this juncture, why begin to loosen the range on spending and invest in gro
componenttext: Obviously, you're coming off the bottom, you saw progress in the second half of 2009. Obviously, demand is not where you ultimately would like it to be. I guess the question is, at this juncture, why begin to loosen the range on spending and invest in growth when it's not clear, at least from your comments, when the growth is going to ultimately come back? And maybe one question to ask, one answer I would guess if you're earning $3 a share, but given where you are right now, might it not be a good idea to keep the reins tight?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We continued to fund a number of our longer-term investment programs during the year to pan RFID, some new developmental materials in our Pressure-sensitive Materials businesses. And then in Office Products, we're going to launch some new products, becaus
componenttext: We continued to fund a number of our longer-term investment programs during the year to pan RFID, some new developmental materials in our Pressure-sensitive Materials businesses. And then in Office Products, we're going to launch some new products, because we feel we have some real opportunities there. We're not going to go crazy here. We're going to invest prudently. And frankly, we're still focused on the productivity to enable us to pay that. And I'd think most of the "news spending and marketing" is simply a shift in resources. And some of that is investment in new people and new marketing folks in some of our geographies and some new verticals. And frankly, I think it's prudent for us to do that. And as the economy begins to recover, it'll give us more acceleration as we come out of it. But we're going to balance this the right way, and continue to make the right decisions on both on the short term and the long term.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess just the point I'd make is the return required in the investment, now that you're making is a lot higher than it would be presumably down the road.  So I hope you'll get a good return on it.
componenttext: I guess just the point I'd make is the return required in the investment, now that you're making is a lot higher than it would be presumably down the road.  So I hope you'll get a good return on it.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: George, let me just add too that the number does on a reported basis report spiked up quite a bit in the quarter. And looking down at the components, some of it is currency, about $10 million. It's up $40 million from the run rate of the first half of the
componenttext: George, let me just add too that the number does on a reported basis report spiked up quite a bit in the quarter. And looking down at the components, some of it is currency, about $10 million. It's up $40 million from the run rate of the first half of the year. Big chunk of that is currency. The fourth quarter has some one offset and the bonus accruals we talked about, $15 million to $20 million of that hit the SG&A line. We also had an unusual quarter in a couple of other areas. We did a fair amount of tax work this quarter which is going to have a lot of benefit on our tax rate going forward as we repatriate cash and so on. So it was high. We're sensitive to the fact that it was high. I don't think it's going to stay that high, it'll come back down a bit. But the key part of this that will continue are some of those investments that being talked about. That part won't go away. So I think we're going to be somewhere between that 325 number and 335 or 340 on an ongoing basis rather than the number we had in the fourth. Hope that helps.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just based on the strength in your free cash flow and you comments on inventories, it sounds like that you might have run the quarter for cash, maybe a bit more so than normal. Can you confirm if that in fact was the case and is there a way to quantify th
componenttext: Just based on the strength in your free cash flow and you comments on inventories, it sounds like that you might have run the quarter for cash, maybe a bit more so than normal. Can you confirm if that in fact was the case and is there a way to quantify the impact on EPS?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've quantified the kind of the major impacts. One of it was the change in the bonus because we did, as you recall, beginning of last year, we changed our incentive programs to emphasize free cash flow. Not totally, but the teams did a real
componenttext: Well, I think we've quantified the kind of the major impacts. One of it was the change in the bonus because we did, as you recall, beginning of last year, we changed our incentive programs to emphasize free cash flow. Not totally, but the teams did a really good job because of that, and I'm glad they did. I think this level is sustainable, and it's the result of literally hundreds of projects in factories and plants and businesses all over the world. And I think people definitely overachieved their targets. So that was a big impact. And then the fact that inventory did fall, again it causes our fixed charge complement to hit the P&L as well. It's not something that we have anticipated.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just given the raw material cost environment, can you just update us on pricing across your businesses?
componenttext: And just given the raw material cost environment, can you just update us on pricing across your businesses?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we announced in the Pressure-sensitive Materials business, we announced price increases in the fourth quarter for 2010. Today, we announced the price increase for our Raw Materials businesses in the United States, in the Americas, actually. And a
componenttext: Sure. So we announced in the Pressure-sensitive Materials business, we announced price increases in the fourth quarter for 2010. Today, we announced the price increase for our Raw Materials businesses in the United States, in the Americas, actually. And also, looking at a couple of other businesses, are reviewing other options right now, so we definitely see an uptick in raw material costs, which is not surprising. So we're going to get out there and raise prices.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Roberts from Buckingham Research Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Roberts from Buckingham Research Group.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: One, the dividend was reduced earlier this year. I thought one of the primary reasons given was that in the event of no recovery in 2010, you were facing, maybe having to finance pension contribution in 2011. Have you had a chance to refine that now that
componenttext: One, the dividend was reduced earlier this year. I thought one of the primary reasons given was that in the event of no recovery in 2010, you were facing, maybe having to finance pension contribution in 2011. Have you had a chance to refine that now that we're maybe getting 12 month away from it?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we did accelerate the pension contribution that would've been due in the U.S. in 2010 into '09, so we made the $25 million contribution last year that was not required. I think this year, we're going to do something similar, and between the U.S. and
componenttext: Well, we did accelerate the pension contribution that would've been due in the U.S. in 2010 into '09, so we made the $25 million contribution last year that was not required. I think this year, we're going to do something similar, and between the U.S. and foreign markets, there's probably around $50 million that will go in. We've seen an improvement obviously in the pension assets but we've also seen a reduction in the discount rate. So our obligations haven't changed materially. And in 2011, we will still see the cost of our U.S. pensions in particular rising.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I thought it was like north of $100 million in 2011. I thought there was like a...
componenttext: I thought it was like north of $100 million in 2011. I thought there was like a...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's not that high. It's a $200 million spread over the years between now and 2013, $200 million to $300 million. So the pension cost but now might be in the $25 million range for U.S. pensions can ramp up into the $70 million to $80 million range per
componenttext: No, it's not that high. It's a $200 million spread over the years between now and 2013, $200 million to $300 million. So the pension cost but now might be in the $25 million range for U.S. pensions can ramp up into the $70 million to $80 million range per year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You indicated you took some market sure in office products. Where would that have been in the office products mix, and what are you doing, why would that happen?
componenttext: You indicated you took some market sure in office products. Where would that have been in the office products mix, and what are you doing, why would that happen?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, I would say mainly it came at the expense of private label, most of it. But as we look at the numbers, customers, I think, are looking for paying for value, and our product provides great value. And some of our direct customers, frankly, have d
componenttext: Basically, I would say mainly it came at the expense of private label, most of it. But as we look at the numbers, customers, I think, are looking for paying for value, and our product provides great value. And some of our direct customers, frankly, have decided that in some categories, that private label just didn't make as much sense, so they simply devoted a little more shelf space to some of our branded products.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Private label provides pretty good value, though. I mean...
componenttext: Private label provides pretty good value, though. I mean...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: On the eye of the beholder.
componenttext: On the eye of the beholder.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So to shift upwards to a higher price point? What's going on? It just seems a little inconsiderate with the market price.
componenttext: So to shift upwards to a higher price point? What's going on? It just seems a little inconsiderate with the market price.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Facts are facts, and we took a little bit of market share, and I think there just wasn't enough traffic on some of the private label products, because customers weren't buying enough.
componenttext: Facts are facts, and we took a little bit of market share, and I think there just wasn't enough traffic on some of the private label products, because customers weren't buying enough.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Ruschmeier from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Peter Ruschmeier from Barclays Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify perhaps, Dean, if you could. The fixed cost absorption that you incurred related to the inventory piece, how much was that piece that you incurred?
componenttext: Just to clarify perhaps, Dean, if you could. The fixed cost absorption that you incurred related to the inventory piece, how much was that piece that you incurred?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It was about $7 million to $8 million year-over-year impact.
componenttext: It was about $7 million to $8 million year-over-year impact.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And on your price hikes, you mentioned that went out today. Can you quantify what the price hikes are, and do you feel, can you elaborate on how confident you feel on those price increases helping to offset whatever kind of cost you may be facing?
componenttext: And on your price hikes, you mentioned that went out today. Can you quantify what the price hikes are, and do you feel, can you elaborate on how confident you feel on those price increases helping to offset whatever kind of cost you may be facing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: To be honest, I can't remember the exact price range. I think it's in the mid-single-digit range. And pretty confident, a couple of other competitors have already announced in the same space. So customers aren't happy, but they're also not surprised.
componenttext: To be honest, I can't remember the exact price range. I think it's in the mid-single-digit range. And pretty confident, a couple of other competitors have already announced in the same space. So customers aren't happy, but they're also not surprised.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the raw material cost side, broadly speaking, do you feel confident these prices can more than offset any cost pressure that you're facing?
componenttext: And on the raw material cost side, broadly speaking, do you feel confident these prices can more than offset any cost pressure that you're facing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the goal. We don't want to lose margin. There's sometimes a bit of a GAAP in terms of how quickly we can get our prices up versus how fast raw materials go up. It's interesting, if the economy really does heat up, I would expect that GAAP to b
componenttext: Yes, that's the goal. We don't want to lose margin. There's sometimes a bit of a GAAP in terms of how quickly we can get our prices up versus how fast raw materials go up. It's interesting, if the economy really does heat up, I would expect that GAAP to be a little tougher. I think if we had 5%, 6%, 7% growth rates in that scenario, raw material costs just start to accelerate pretty rapidly. So it could be a little bit of a damper on us as we move forward.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a quick one for Dan if I could. Terrific working capital performance, I'm curious as you look to 2010, as you've provided some guidance for free cash flow, what have you incorporated in your thinking in terms of whether working capital is a
componenttext: And maybe just a quick one for Dan if I could. Terrific working capital performance, I'm curious as you look to 2010, as you've provided some guidance for free cash flow, what have you incorporated in your thinking in terms of whether working capital is a use or source of cash?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think our first objective is to sustain the significant improvement we got this year. And unfortunately, it's not all a Q4 event. Through the year, we saw improvements in inventories and other areas. So I feel good about the way it's been implemented. O
componenttext: I think our first objective is to sustain the significant improvement we got this year. And unfortunately, it's not all a Q4 event. Through the year, we saw improvements in inventories and other areas. So I feel good about the way it's been implemented. Our objective will be to sustain it. I don't anticipate another big slug of productivity on the working capital line next year. Having said that if we do hit the higher end of the sales line, the kinds of numbers that it might re-absorb would be in the tens of millions of dollars. I don't anticipate anything that would take us back where we were. I think it's primarily, predominantly sustainable productivity.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In the talk about bonus accruals, as I understood it you said that they were up $25 million or so year-over-year. What were they up sequentially?
componenttext: In the talk about bonus accruals, as I understood it you said that they were up $25 million or so year-over-year. What were they up sequentially?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It wasn't nearly that, probably about a third of that number sequentially.
componenttext: It wasn't nearly that, probably about a third of that number sequentially.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So I'm a little puzzled as to the magnitude of the cost-reduction, and that your SG&A expense sequentially went up about $18 million and your cost of goods sold was basically flat, and your revenues were down a little bit. So if some of the SG&A inflation
componenttext: So I'm a little puzzled as to the magnitude of the cost-reduction, and that your SG&A expense sequentially went up about $18 million and your cost of goods sold was basically flat, and your revenues were down a little bit. So if some of the SG&A inflation has to do with the bonus accruals, where's the net cost savings? And how do you measure it versus the third quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In specifically in the G&A area, there was some productivity. It was a few million dollars. But it wasn't a huge jump sequentially from quarter-to-quarter. There were currency impacts, some of the discretionary spending that Dean talked about in -- it was
componenttext: In specifically in the G&A area, there was some productivity. It was a few million dollars. But it wasn't a huge jump sequentially from quarter-to-quarter. There were currency impacts, some of the discretionary spending that Dean talked about in -- it was incurred sequentially, not just year on year. That was a few million dollars again.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And there's a mix impact too, Jeff. So the businesses that have the highest margin had the softest sales in the quarter relative to Q3.
componenttext: And there's a mix impact too, Jeff. So the businesses that have the highest margin had the softest sales in the quarter relative to Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the working capital improvement, at least by my calculations from your previous quarter press release, it looks like your receivables went down about $90 million and your payables went up $40 million. So I guess -- and those seem to be the lar
componenttext: In terms of the working capital improvement, at least by my calculations from your previous quarter press release, it looks like your receivables went down about $90 million and your payables went up $40 million. So I guess -- and those seem to be the largest changes that boosted free cash flow. So how did the receivables come down so much? Were incentives offered to the people that had to pay them, or -- how do you do that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't have any incentives specifically around receivables but we did on cash flow. And so a number of our businesses had initiatives for the year to improve it particularly in Asia. We did a great job over there of collecting in a difficult environmen
componenttext: We didn't have any incentives specifically around receivables but we did on cash flow. And so a number of our businesses had initiatives for the year to improve it particularly in Asia. We did a great job over there of collecting in a difficult environment. I take my hat off to the folks that are in that end of things. They did a good job. Our losses in a tough environment have been extremely low, and they did a good job of managing through this. There is a seasonality factor to some extent here or perhaps better said a timing factor because last year, we ended the year on the -- late December. Did year, we ended the year early January. So some of what I said about sustainability in working capital is related to that timing. We did get some collections in the last couple of days of the fiscal year that we relayed to [ph] early January, but it wasn't a big number. I think most of this was driven by several days of improvement in our DSO.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In your slides you say that you're going to push your cost down net by about $70 million year-over-year. So your SG&A is around 1269. So if that grew 3%, that's about $38 million? So half of 70 is 35, so is the goal to keep your SG&A expense flat year-ove
componenttext: In your slides you say that you're going to push your cost down net by about $70 million year-over-year. So your SG&A is around 1269. So if that grew 3%, that's about $38 million? So half of 70 is 35, so is the goal to keep your SG&A expense flat year-over-year next year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, because the first half of '09 where we ran about $300 million a quarter was really below any kind of a sustainable level. We stopped traveling, we did things that you just can't do for very long, and we did it at a time when we needed it, help the cas
componenttext: No, because the first half of '09 where we ran about $300 million a quarter was really below any kind of a sustainable level. We stopped traveling, we did things that you just can't do for very long, and we did it at a time when we needed it, help the cash flow. But I think next year, we're going to have a normalized rate that's in that 330-ish kind of range. It gives us some room for growth investments on top of what we've been doing. And if the economy really soft, we'll be able to pull down from that number as well. But I think more sustainably with the initiatives that we now need to throw a little fuel in the fire for that it's more likely we'll be in that 330 range, give or take.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The margin change in office products was pretty remarkable. Do you see that as an eccentric value or -- how do you think about the general level of Office Products margins going forward?
componenttext: The margin change in office products was pretty remarkable. Do you see that as an eccentric value or -- how do you think about the general level of Office Products margins going forward?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think they're going to be a little bit lower than they have traditionally. I mean, we still have really good productivity from that business. When you look year-over-year, and our sales were down quite a bit, and we're going to invest incrementally
componenttext: Well I think they're going to be a little bit lower than they have traditionally. I mean, we still have really good productivity from that business. When you look year-over-year, and our sales were down quite a bit, and we're going to invest incrementally some more money on marketing dollars to try to grow the top line. And so that's going to cost us a few margin points for the next 18 months or so until we can shore up and start to get some growth in the business.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And let me add too, Jeff. The single biggest factor in the quarter, that sequential drop in the margin was volume related. Some of that's seasonal. And then we talked about strong Q3 going to late Q4. We were down 16% in sales sequentially. So most of wha
componenttext: And let me add too, Jeff. The single biggest factor in the quarter, that sequential drop in the margin was volume related. Some of that's seasonal. And then we talked about strong Q3 going to late Q4. We were down 16% in sales sequentially. So most of what happened here was volume related. And the volumes have been picking up relative to prior year, but they're still pretty negative. So we need to see the consumer come back a little bit there hopefully and see some inventory build.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Naya from UBS Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Naya from UBS Research.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could quantify kind of the -- to the extent you saw inflation creeping in, in the fourth quarter? What kind of magnitude did you see?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could quantify kind of the -- to the extent you saw inflation creeping in, in the fourth quarter? What kind of magnitude did you see?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to get too specific here in particular because we're in the middle of raising prices in a number of places. And any comment I make will be so generalized that it may conflict with some of what was -- we're saying to specific customers and sp
componenttext: I'm not going to get too specific here in particular because we're in the middle of raising prices in a number of places. And any comment I make will be so generalized that it may conflict with some of what was -- we're saying to specific customers and specific units that don't look like the average. But having said that, the raw material impact in the fourth quarter was in the 50 to 70 basis point range on the margin, but it's building. There are a lot of announcements and price increases that were in the process of being given by our suppliers that aren't yet in the fourth quarter. It was just the beginning of a wave.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just kind of a -- taking a step back, you touched on this earlier. What kind of -- I guess sentiment are you picking from your customers? Are you seeing any kind of change or improvement in their outlook, or what kind of feedback are you getting there
componenttext: And just kind of a -- taking a step back, you touched on this earlier. What kind of -- I guess sentiment are you picking from your customers? Are you seeing any kind of change or improvement in their outlook, or what kind of feedback are you getting there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it depends on the customer of course. When you talk to customers in emerging markets, they're all pretty happy, especially in Asia. Things are looking pretty rosy there, it's pretty much fantastic. I think in the retail sector, what I see there is mo
componenttext: Yes, it depends on the customer of course. When you talk to customers in emerging markets, they're all pretty happy, especially in Asia. Things are looking pretty rosy there, it's pretty much fantastic. I think in the retail sector, what I see there is more optimism. Most retailers improve their gross margins this year in the apparel sector mainly because they kept their inventories down, and therefore they didn't have to markdown product as much. And they did see a little better Christmas season than they had expected, so definitely more optimism there. The key question is, how much inventory are they going to put into the system next year. But at least I don't anticipate any more destocking in that sector. So I would say they're cautiously optimistic. In the Pressure-sensitive business, it's kind of a mixed bag. I mean we still have a number of businesses in that sector that are economy related. And our Graphics business, it's more related to promotional activities and corporate rebranding activities. Not a lot of activity there yet in terms of selling, although there's talking. And I think in Pressure-sensitive, there's kind of cautious, I think, in the Roll business. I think I said this at the end of the last call, when I was at the Labelexpo show in Brussels, I was surprised how optimistic the label converters were there. We recently had a meeting with our North American customers and they were I'd say moderately optimistic. So not as enthusiastic as people in other parts of the world.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on China, clearly that's been a real nice positive for you guys. There's been some concern around the government kind of stepping back and pulling away some of the stimulus there. Have you seen or heard anything that gives you any pause?
componenttext: And just on China, clearly that's been a real nice positive for you guys. There's been some concern around the government kind of stepping back and pulling away some of the stimulus there. Have you seen or heard anything that gives you any pause?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again in the Pressure-sensitive business, our business there tends to be driven more by domestic demand with a rising middle class. And I think even in our worst quarter in that business last year, I can't remember when it was now. But we had one qu
componenttext: Well, again in the Pressure-sensitive business, our business there tends to be driven more by domestic demand with a rising middle class. And I think even in our worst quarter in that business last year, I can't remember when it was now. But we had one quarter or two were flat growth, and then it rebounded pretty quickly to double-digit. So I don't really anticipate a whole lot. The Export business is still good going out of China and I anticipate think will be better certainly than last year. I don't know. You never know though. The government over there needs to employ people. So I think they'll probably lean more to a stimulus and be cautious about ramping back too quickly.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of John McNulty from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of John McNulty from Credit Suisse.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Pressure-sensitive market, can you give us some clarity as to what may be going on in terms of the competitive environment and if the industry as a whole appears to be disciplined right now with pricing now that raws are starting to go up? Or if th
componenttext: In the Pressure-sensitive market, can you give us some clarity as to what may be going on in terms of the competitive environment and if the industry as a whole appears to be disciplined right now with pricing now that raws are starting to go up? Or if there's still a little bit of slippage, and how we should think about that going forward?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. John, I think we -- last year, it seemed to me that most of the companies in the industry were trying to improve their margins. I mean -- and that has been the most important thing and I think I sense that going forward as well. Especially for a lot
componenttext: Yes. John, I think we -- last year, it seemed to me that most of the companies in the industry were trying to improve their margins. I mean -- and that has been the most important thing and I think I sense that going forward as well. Especially for a lot of the smaller competitors, they probably don't have as easy access to credit markets as we do or UPM Raflatac does. And I think their sources of capital were saying, you guys need to make some money and protect your margins. So I anticipate this environment continuing on, to be honest. I mean it's -- seems to me it's to be -- when raw material prices go up now, everybody is implementing price increases.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then a question on your guidance. I understand it's tough in this kind of an economic environment to nail down exactly what sales or volume growth is going to look like. But in the two range that you put out, one of them included an organic sales scen
componenttext: And then a question on your guidance. I understand it's tough in this kind of an economic environment to nail down exactly what sales or volume growth is going to look like. But in the two range that you put out, one of them included an organic sales scenario where you saw flat sales. Now considering that you saw huge inventory destocking at the customer level in 2009, what possible scenario could get you to have a flat organic sales line for 2010? Or is there a business that may have broken throughout the recession where we should just be thinking about it differently going forward?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think you should take that as we're concerned about a flat year, or trying to project anything in that. It's just a different discipline we're employing. Basically, at the behest of the Board to bracket out our scenario planning, so that we'v
componenttext: Yes. I don't think you should take that as we're concerned about a flat year, or trying to project anything in that. It's just a different discipline we're employing. Basically, at the behest of the Board to bracket out our scenario planning, so that we've got levers to pull in case something either really bad happens or things get a lot more positive. And I think it's just more of a planning exercise and scenario. Frankly let's face it, it's a bell curve. I think zero is pretty unprobable. The only way that could happen is if we went into some kind of major economic crisis or double dip recession. I don't anticipate that happening today. On the other hand, there's not a 0% probability that would happen either.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: With that said, knowing there's a lot of variables out there, what is your best stab at what you think your organic sales going to be in terms of 2010? I mean not nailing you down to a specific number but...
componenttext: With that said, knowing there's a lot of variables out there, what is your best stab at what you think your organic sales going to be in terms of 2010? I mean not nailing you down to a specific number but...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Let's face it, the first half of the year is going to look great because the comps will be incredibly easy. And the real question is in my mind, what's the back half of the year look like? Is this economy going to be sustainable? There's been a lot of gov
componenttext: Let's face it, the first half of the year is going to look great because the comps will be incredibly easy. And the real question is in my mind, what's the back half of the year look like? Is this economy going to be sustainable? There's been a lot of government stimulus in a number of economies, will that continue? Will the Feds start to tighten up in the back half of the year and will that crimp demand? And if they don't, will we see rapid inflation? I mean so there's a lot of factors and variables that I'd say, hey look -- are impacting us. And basically my attitude is, look, let's plan on a moderate recovery, and if things don't go the way that we planned we know what levers we have to pull and we'll do it immediately.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: John, I hope what you take away from this, which was the intent was not to target anybody in. If we had used 3 to 5, I think everybody would have assumed the three was guidance. So we're trying no to do that. The economy is going to be a real swing factor
componenttext: John, I hope what you take away from this, which was the intent was not to target anybody in. If we had used 3 to 5, I think everybody would have assumed the three was guidance. So we're trying no to do that. The economy is going to be a real swing factor in revenue this year and either the low end or the high end of that range will imply some impact of the economy beyond what's within our control. The focus here though, and the reason we used the scenario planning of the board is to demonstrate that free cash flow is going to be solid either way. And we don't have any liquidity issues or anything like that. We'll be able to support all of the growth initiatives and other things. Free cash flow will be the focus coming out of that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly don't anticipate a meltdown in one of our businesses, so there's no signal implied there.
componenttext: We certainly don't anticipate a meltdown in one of our businesses, so there's no signal implied there.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from George Staphos from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a last question again on the level of investment spending. Would it be fair, just using your comments, and what you're suggesting SG&A can look like, MG&A can look like for next year, that the level of reinvestment and things like marketing and admin
componenttext: Just a last question again on the level of investment spending. Would it be fair, just using your comments, and what you're suggesting SG&A can look like, MG&A can look like for next year, that the level of reinvestment and things like marketing and admin behind the businesses is around $30 million, $40 million, and if that's a fair assumption, how would you generally parse that across your segments?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In total, that's about right, George. The greater part of that growth-related spending, there is some infrastructure spending. The infrastructure part is primarily weighted into two places, RIS where we continue to pull these businesses that are spre
componenttext: Yes. In total, that's about right, George. The greater part of that growth-related spending, there is some infrastructure spending. The infrastructure part is primarily weighted into two places, RIS where we continue to pull these businesses that are spread around the world together from a systems perspective. So a good part of our capital spend for the year, not a majority or anything but a significant part of the capital spend is supporting RIS, and some of that is their systems. The Roll Materials business also has had a capital project going on in their systems front and that will wrap up during the next 12 months or so. So most of what is in for structural is related to the level of IT spend going on in those projects. Some of it is pension. We got a fairly good slug of pension increase going on year on year that's relevant as well. But half to two thirds of this is related to growth initiatives and some of the new platforms coming out of a couple of our businesses. Some of that's in the Roll business, they've got a couple of areas of growth that Dean spoke about, Office Products are doing some. So it's spread around, but a lot of it is related to the infrastructure part to IT initiatives.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: But that infrastructure part wouldn't necessarily be showing up in MG&A, whether it would obviously in your CapEx and IT spend, right? Or is that incorrect?
componenttext: But that infrastructure part wouldn't necessarily be showing up in MG&A, whether it would obviously in your CapEx and IT spend, right? Or is that incorrect?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Some of it is. But a lot -- there is still ongoing expense that happens on the basically on the SG&A line when you put some new systems in.
componenttext: Some of it is. But a lot -- there is still ongoing expense that happens on the basically on the SG&A line when you put some new systems in.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How much are you actually putting into Office Products? I know it's [ph] your biggest segment and I don't want to belabor, but just out of curiosity?
componenttext: How much are you actually putting into Office Products? I know it's [ph] your biggest segment and I don't want to belabor, but just out of curiosity?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The incremental investment is in the mid-single-digit millions I'd say on an annual basis. But the amount of spend for marketing initiatives is actually higher because what we've done is figured out a way to re-purpose on our cost in the business, elimina
componenttext: The incremental investment is in the mid-single-digit millions I'd say on an annual basis. But the amount of spend for marketing initiatives is actually higher because what we've done is figured out a way to re-purpose on our cost in the business, eliminating them but just shifting them more to growth activity.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: How did your end of the quarter progress? Did you see December continue to trend higher versus earlier months in the year? Did you see slowdown as the year wound down? What kind of trends are you seeing earlier in the year? And in particular, be focused m
componenttext: How did your end of the quarter progress? Did you see December continue to trend higher versus earlier months in the year? Did you see slowdown as the year wound down? What kind of trends are you seeing earlier in the year? And in particular, be focused mostly in your answer on the Pressure-sensitive business and RIS business in U.S. and in Europe? Well I realize RIS is more Asia, but ...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. But RIS actually kind of sailed right to the end of the quarter, I would say continually strengthening through the quarter. Pressure-sensitive slowed down at the end of the year, but that's normal. So I didn't sense any unusual trends there. I think
componenttext: Yes. But RIS actually kind of sailed right to the end of the quarter, I would say continually strengthening through the quarter. Pressure-sensitive slowed down at the end of the year, but that's normal. So I didn't sense any unusual trends there. I think those were probably the two major momentum factors. The other thing that's a little complicated is that our last two weeks of the year were both holiday weeks which is a little unusual. So all in all, everything was a little weak ending the year but we expected that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And January has started out reasonably in line with your expectations?
componenttext: And January has started out reasonably in line with your expectations?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, especially considering how bad January was last year. The comps are incredibly easy.
componenttext: Yes, especially considering how bad January was last year. The comps are incredibly easy.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Temple Houston from Prudential Investors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Temple Houston from Prudential Investors.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You've done a good job, I guess you paid down $300 million of debt. And I think your original target was to pay down $350 million by the end of 2010. So I wondered if that implies that you're only going to pay down an additional $50 million this year? Or
componenttext: You've done a good job, I guess you paid down $300 million of debt. And I think your original target was to pay down $350 million by the end of 2010. So I wondered if that implies that you're only going to pay down an additional $50 million this year? Or maybe you're going to pay down a little more than $350 million?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think what you should take from that is that, that goal is out the window. We'll be establishing a new goal with free cash flow and the $300 million to $350 million range next year, we would expect to pay down again a substantial amount of debt. And
componenttext: No. I think what you should take from that is that, that goal is out the window. We'll be establishing a new goal with free cash flow and the $300 million to $350 million range next year, we would expect to pay down again a substantial amount of debt. And being approaching our debt targets late in the year, late third or fourth quarter, we generate almost all or all of our free cash flow actually in the second half of the year because of seasonal factors. So we expect to hit our targets late next year, and we're well in course to do so. We really superseded the previous objective.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just remind me what those targets are?
componenttext: Could you just remind me what those targets are?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't set any targets specifically. But our overall objective is to get our credit rating back where it was. We were downgraded about a year ago. And it's important to us to keep access to commercial paper markets which we have today. So we'd l
componenttext: Well, we haven't set any targets specifically. But our overall objective is to get our credit rating back where it was. We were downgraded about a year ago. And it's important to us to keep access to commercial paper markets which we have today. So we'd like to see the rating go back up. So I think we can hit ratios that the agencies look at late in 2010 and be able to sustain that level and have free cash flow beyond debt repayment at that time for other purposes, particularly returning money to shareholders.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010

componenttextpreview: I was curious if you could help us to better understand the impact of capital spending from your customers coming down in the last 12 months, and how that's impacted you? And then obviously on the flip side, the extent that you're talking to your customer
componenttext: I was curious if you could help us to better understand the impact of capital spending from your customers coming down in the last 12 months, and how that's impacted you? And then obviously on the flip side, the extent that you're talking to your customers who are indicating plans to increase your CapEx to facilitate more demand for some of your DSM and retail RIS products?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not sure I completely understand the question. I think most in the Pressure-sensitive area, again I sensed a pickup and I don't have any data here. But I did sense a pickup in terms of the amount of activity with the press manufacturers, the prin
componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure I completely understand the question. I think most in the Pressure-sensitive area, again I sensed a pickup and I don't have any data here. But I did sense a pickup in terms of the amount of activity with the press manufacturers, the printing press manufacturers that our customers buy. This is more anecdotal than anything else. But I'm talking to a few of the executives in our industry. They seem to be more optimistic. But that being said, of course the first half of the year was an absolute disaster so -- from a comparative basis, it's a little better. Still healthy investment levels in emerging markets though, with the press capacity being added there. In RIS, it was not really a factor, the apparel industry is not a capital intensive business, so they can kind of turn on and off, and sewing machines aren't very expensive. They can kind of turn stuff on and off at will.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So not to put words in your mouth, but it sounds like, Dean, maybe it's -- from your perspective, less relevant as to whether or not they've been placing more orders or printing presses as to whether that's really impacting your business directly?
componenttext: So not to put words in your mouth, but it sounds like, Dean, maybe it's -- from your perspective, less relevant as to whether or not they've been placing more orders or printing presses as to whether that's really impacting your business directly?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's hard to do. Here's why. There's been a lot of investment in digital technology especially in the printing industry because it's more productive in running short runs and it adds capability. And so some customers, including ourselves, we run a lo
componenttext: Yes, it's hard to do. Here's why. There's been a lot of investment in digital technology especially in the printing industry because it's more productive in running short runs and it adds capability. And so some customers, including ourselves, we run a lot more on our RIS business across our digital process than we have some of our older offset presses and our volumes are still down. We're just able to process those lines at a different productivity level. So it's not a very good proxy for -- it's a proxy for business confidence, but not necessarily a proxy for increased demand short-term.

componenttext: I think you indicated that the cash cost related to the restructuring, I believe you said was about 70% of the $160 million. So about $110 million. componenttext: In other specialty converting, in the third quarter you made $6 million and then in the fourth you lost $5 million. So you had an $11 million change, and your revenues I think were down at about $11 million. Can you talk about what happened in that business?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the numbers are relatively small in the business units and can move around a bit. There were a couple of unusual charges in the fourth quarter that hurt earnings. The revenue sequentially was down about 8% in this business. So again the biggest facto
componenttext: Yes, the numbers are relatively small in the business units and can move around a bit. There were a couple of unusual charges in the fourth quarter that hurt earnings. The revenue sequentially was down about 8% in this business. So again the biggest factor was fixed cost leverage and there were some mix issues. So there was -- about half of it was unusual things that don't repeat, the other half was either mix or fixed cost leverage on lower volumes.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly in Pressure-sensitive Materials, basically your revenues were flat sequentially, but your operating income went down $20 million. And I guess some of that is bonus accruals, and some of that is raw materials. Is that all of it, or some of
componenttext: And then lastly in Pressure-sensitive Materials, basically your revenues were flat sequentially, but your operating income went down $20 million. And I guess some of that is bonus accruals, and some of that is raw materials. Is that all of it, or some of it? And how are you doing in reducing costs in that business?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, there's some mix too. I think some of the businesses that have higher margins were a little softer in the quarter than in the third quarter. I think our cost reduction, I mean the gross margin improvement year-over-year especially if you look a
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, there's some mix too. I think some of the businesses that have higher margins were a little softer in the quarter than in the third quarter. I think our cost reduction, I mean the gross margin improvement year-over-year especially if you look at the first half to the second half has been phenomenal actually. Our gross margins in that business are as high as they've been in the last 3 to 4 years. We finally recovered all that raw material inflation that we've lagged. We've taken a lot of fixed cost out of the supply chain. And so I actually think it's in pretty good shape right now. So a little volume will go a long way in terms of driving good returns in that business.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think too, Jeff. While the reported numbers were flat organically, it was down a little bit more than that. Probably more like 3% instead of -- the minus 1% sequentially. But -- so you get some leverage issues, bonus accruals. We talked about raw materi
componenttext: I think too, Jeff. While the reported numbers were flat organically, it was down a little bit more than that. Probably more like 3% instead of -- the minus 1% sequentially. But -- so you get some leverage issues, bonus accruals. We talked about raw material being around 70 basis points of the margin compression. And then so there's a variety of things, nothing real specific other than the bonus which was -- the other half of the company generated the vast majority of that extra cash.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-29-2010
