componenttext: Hey, was there a negative mix in the Office Products business at a year-over-year basis? Core sales were down 2%, but operating profit was down north of 20%, and this is a presumably a low-cost structure. So just trying to understand the disconnect between the two.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think there is much of a mix impact, Ghansham. We were investing money in both innovation and the space on new product development. We're also spending some money to improve our marketing programs with customers. So that's really the major im
componenttext: Yes, I don't think there is much of a mix impact, Ghansham. We were investing money in both innovation and the space on new product development. We're also spending some money to improve our marketing programs with customers. So that's really the major impact on the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the competitive environment to the RIS business, there's, I think, one of your competitors, in particular, that seems to be targeting this business more aggressively. Curious on whether this has impacted pricing?
componenttext: And in terms of the competitive environment to the RIS business, there's, I think, one of your competitors, in particular, that seems to be targeting this business more aggressively. Curious on whether this has impacted pricing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. Right now, we're in a situation where the order books are pretty full, I think, not only for us but across the whole industry. My sense is that retailers are trying to catch up a bit. And as a result, their focus is on getting product ra
componenttext: I don't think so. Right now, we're in a situation where the order books are pretty full, I think, not only for us but across the whole industry. My sense is that retailers are trying to catch up a bit. And as a result, their focus is on getting product rather than reducing costs.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, finally, Dan, you gave us some parameters on 2Q. But isn't it also true that RIS typically is stronger, 2Q versus 1Q?
componenttext: And then, finally, Dan, you gave us some parameters on 2Q. But isn't it also true that RIS typically is stronger, 2Q versus 1Q?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. First quarter is the weakest quarter in this business, seasonally. And we are feeling the effect of the typical seasonal order surge right now.
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. First quarter is the weakest quarter in this business, seasonally. And we are feeling the effect of the typical seasonal order surge right now.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mr. George Staphos, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mr. George Staphos, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first question I had, when I parsed some of your comments along with the guidance commentary at the back of this PDF, what I'm winding up with is that maybe inflation this year, net of wherever pricing you get in, costs you about $0.20, $0.25 fro
componenttext: I guess, first question I had, when I parsed some of your comments along with the guidance commentary at the back of this PDF, what I'm winding up with is that maybe inflation this year, net of wherever pricing you get in, costs you about $0.20, $0.25 from what you would have otherwise earned. Would you provide any additional color, or agree or disagree with that number?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I'm not going to put a number on it, George, because it's tough to predict exactly the rate of inflation and how fast you can get your prices up. But just as we have said in the January call, one of the concerns we had was, if the economy wa
componenttext: Well, I think I'm not going to put a number on it, George, because it's tough to predict exactly the rate of inflation and how fast you can get your prices up. But just as we have said in the January call, one of the concerns we had was, if the economy was rebounding quickly, that we would see an imbalance of supply and demand in some raw materials. And that's exactly what we're starting to experience now. So we'll get the prices where we need to get them. But it's awfully hard, as you know, to match that quarter-for-quarter. We saw a little bit of that in the fourth quarter last year, and we managed to catch up somewhat in Q1. And we're raising prices now. So fundamentally, that is, from my perspective, the biggest drag on the year. I think, in the long run, it won't be a drag. But in a year's context, it will be.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would add, too, George, that in the low end of the guidance range we gave versus the high end, the raw material inflationary impact and our ability to cover pricing, early versus late, is a key factor in moving us between the two ends of the guidance ra
componenttext: I would add, too, George, that in the low end of the guidance range we gave versus the high end, the raw material inflationary impact and our ability to cover pricing, early versus late, is a key factor in moving us between the two ends of the guidance range.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing, George, too, don't forget we're going to be spending some more money on office products, as part of our offense is a good defense strategy in that sector. So that's a little bit more than we had anticipated in the beginning of the
componenttext: I think the other thing, George, too, don't forget we're going to be spending some more money on office products, as part of our offense is a good defense strategy in that sector. So that's a little bit more than we had anticipated in the beginning of the year as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe as a follow-on to that, within your inputs, are you seeing more pressure at this juncture from resins and related products? Or are you seeing it more from specialty papers?
componenttext: Maybe as a follow-on to that, within your inputs, are you seeing more pressure at this juncture from resins and related products? Or are you seeing it more from specialty papers?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it depends on the categories. Let me be specific. Right now, acrylic monomers are pretty tight. And while it has not impacted our ability to ship, we've had, had to go out in the spot market and buy some product to ensure supply, which is obviously
componenttext: Well, it depends on the categories. Let me be specific. Right now, acrylic monomers are pretty tight. And while it has not impacted our ability to ship, we've had, had to go out in the spot market and buy some product to ensure supply, which is obviously a little more expensive at this point. Pulp is also still high, and then especially because, I think, after the earthquake in Chile, demand is up a little bit as well. There's a bit of tightness there, as well as in the specialty paper category, especially for Liner. We'll see how long that lasts. But it's a little tight in a few categories. A lot of producers, frankly, cut way back last year when demand was down. And now we're feeling the other side of that equation.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Specifically within Europe, what kind of trends are you seeing with either RIS or Pressure-sensitive Materials? Have you seen some improvement in volume for what you might have been seeing earlier in the quarter year-on-year? How have trends progressed?
componenttext: Specifically within Europe, what kind of trends are you seeing with either RIS or Pressure-sensitive Materials? Have you seen some improvement in volume for what you might have been seeing earlier in the quarter year-on-year? How have trends progressed?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eastern Europe's actually been quite strong. And so that has brought up the average. I mean, if you look at Europe as the average, it actually -- their organic growth rate was similar to the U.S. But if you pull out Eastern Europe, the number drops.
componenttext: Yes, Eastern Europe's actually been quite strong. And so that has brought up the average. I mean, if you look at Europe as the average, it actually -- their organic growth rate was similar to the U.S. But if you pull out Eastern Europe, the number drops. I think, from an RIS perspective, retailers in Europe are not seeing the increases in demand that U.S. retailers are. I'd still think they're a little bit lagging behind. The Pressure-sensitive business actually had a pretty good quarter in Europe in Q1. So I'm not sure what that says yet. But my sense is, we're still not at that same level as robust a recovery as we see in North America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, it means RIS will pick up in six months, right?
componenttext: Hopefully, it means RIS will pick up in six months, right?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It'd be great if everything in Europe picked up in six months.
componenttext: It'd be great if everything in Europe picked up in six months.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Silke Kueck for Jeff. A couple of questions, on the Pressure-sensitive Materials side, where are you in terms of price increase? Meaning, it seems that some price increases were announced earlier in the year. And so can you just talk about what ha
componenttext: This is Silke Kueck for Jeff. A couple of questions, on the Pressure-sensitive Materials side, where are you in terms of price increase? Meaning, it seems that some price increases were announced earlier in the year. And so can you just talk about what has been announced and where are you trying to get to by year-end?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We started raising prices, as you said, in January. We had a little bit of negative pressure in some markets in the late stages of the third quarter into the fourth quarter. Obviously, the inflation has reversed that trend, and we started raising them in
componenttext: We started raising prices, as you said, in January. We had a little bit of negative pressure in some markets in the late stages of the third quarter into the fourth quarter. Obviously, the inflation has reversed that trend, and we started raising them in the first quarter. As the inflation has accelerated, we're accelerating additional price increases. So most regions in the world are seeing a second round happening, as we speak, that we'll roll out during the second quarter. I think all of the competition is feeling the same inflation, and it seems that most players in the market are raising prices at the same time.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when it's all implemented, which may take until like next year, should that lead to like 1% higher prices or 2% higher prices? Or maybe it seems that's the order of magnitude, what you need to offset a 3% raw material head?
componenttext: And when it's all implemented, which may take until like next year, should that lead to like 1% higher prices or 2% higher prices? Or maybe it seems that's the order of magnitude, what you need to offset a 3% raw material head?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's right. We expect to fully recover that on a dollar basis. That's going to add a couple of points, at least, to the revenue line. It's not all of our businesses here that are experiencing inflation the same way. So it will be higher in our mat
componenttext: Well, that's right. We expect to fully recover that on a dollar basis. That's going to add a couple of points, at least, to the revenue line. It's not all of our businesses here that are experiencing inflation the same way. So it will be higher in our materials sector, obviously, but lower in some other parts of the business that don't get hit with the inflation.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of volume growth, these are very nice results in the Pressure-Sensitive Materials business. Do those seem sustainable to you, given that there may be some -- I know that it's hard to quantify when there's a seasonality in any quarters, but no
componenttext: And in terms of volume growth, these are very nice results in the Pressure-Sensitive Materials business. Do those seem sustainable to you, given that there may be some -- I know that it's hard to quantify when there's a seasonality in any quarters, but normally it seems that the second and third quarters always do a little bit better than the first and the fourth. So are the current volume rates that we see sustainable going into the next quarters?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's sort of the big question. I definitely think we saw some inventory rebuilding, restocking. And certainly, the comps were not easier than normal in the first quarter. We do see continued strength into April. And I mentioned earlier in the call that
componenttext: That's sort of the big question. I definitely think we saw some inventory rebuilding, restocking. And certainly, the comps were not easier than normal in the first quarter. We do see continued strength into April. And I mentioned earlier in the call that we've been adding a lot of marketing capability to call on end-use segment. So our pipeline of forward project continues to grow. So I would characterize the market as having lots of activity, and much of that activity has not yet translated into top line sales. So I'm definitely more optimistic than I was a few months ago.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in RIS, you've mentioned a few times, more like the second quarter all to seem to be seasonally stronger quarter. And so it seems like the activity on the RIS side looks also positive. Should we see the incrementally higher margin benefit in the secon
componenttext: And in RIS, you've mentioned a few times, more like the second quarter all to seem to be seasonally stronger quarter. And so it seems like the activity on the RIS side looks also positive. Should we see the incrementally higher margin benefit in the second quarter versus the first?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Q2 was always RIS's strongest quarter. So the volumes will be higher. And as a result, the incremental margins are higher as well.
componenttext: Absolutely. Q2 was always RIS's strongest quarter. So the volumes will be higher. And as a result, the incremental margins are higher as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So what we should expect is that incrementally, the operating margin should improve in the first and the second quarter, meaningfully?
componenttext: So what we should expect is that incrementally, the operating margin should improve in the first and the second quarter, meaningfully?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and that's generally the case.
componenttext: Yes, and that's generally the case.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly on Office Products, how much of the negative organic growth was due to the competitor on the label side?
componenttext: And lastly on Office Products, how much of the negative organic growth was due to the competitor on the label side?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a volume perspective, here's the way I'll kind of look at it. So we saw the impact of a little bit less destocking than we saw in the prior year. POS trends are still negative. This business is probably going to be the last to recover in an economy b
componenttext: From a volume perspective, here's the way I'll kind of look at it. So we saw the impact of a little bit less destocking than we saw in the prior year. POS trends are still negative. This business is probably going to be the last to recover in an economy because it's pretty much based on white-collar employment. So a lot of it is just, again, investment that we have for new products, for innovation and more attractive consumer programs as we defend the category. So the good news I've heard lately is more anecdotally is that the part of the business that got hurt the most last year was the contracting commercial side of the business versus retail. They both were down, but the contracting commercial was down a lot more. The comps look a little more promising on the commercial side of the business these days. So I've got my fingers crossed that we'll see maybe, hopefully, a little more recovery than we anticipate. The big impact though will be the impact of back-to-school in the second and third quarter. I think we're well positioned to have decent back-to-school this year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I can ask a final question on -- can you discuss where you are in terms cost savings, and as I remember the target was to get to a run rate of $180 million by mid-2010. So where we are at the end of the first quarter, and is it still the target? Wa
componenttext: And if I can ask a final question on -- can you discuss where you are in terms cost savings, and as I remember the target was to get to a run rate of $180 million by mid-2010. So where we are at the end of the first quarter, and is it still the target? Was it higher?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The target is still $180 million. We pulled that up over the last quarter or two. We're virtually finished with the program now. By the end of the second quarter, it will be fully implemented and the run rate will be the full $180 million. We'll still hav
componenttext: The target is still $180 million. We pulled that up over the last quarter or two. We're virtually finished with the program now. By the end of the second quarter, it will be fully implemented and the run rate will be the full $180 million. We'll still have some cash that will trickle out in coming months, obviously. But we delivered about $25 million in incremental savings over the fourth quarter because of these actions. But we're nearing the end of the program we started in the fourth quarter of '08 now.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of John McNulty, Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of John McNulty, Crédit Suisse.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the pressure-sensitive markets, prior to the recession, it looked like the industry had kind of finally found discipline. And I was wondering -- because it got a little bit cloudy through the recession -- but now that we're starting to come
componenttext: With regard to the pressure-sensitive markets, prior to the recession, it looked like the industry had kind of finally found discipline. And I was wondering -- because it got a little bit cloudy through the recession -- but now that we're starting to come out, what are you seeing in terms of the competitive environment? And how is the discipline holding up right now?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think that, certainly, when a couple of our competitors were actually losing money or having negative operating margins for a few quarters after the round of inflation and then recession hit, I sensed certainly a renewed focus on making money. And
componenttext: Well I think that, certainly, when a couple of our competitors were actually losing money or having negative operating margins for a few quarters after the round of inflation and then recession hit, I sensed certainly a renewed focus on making money. And I think that's a good thing. And we're going to continue to raise prices when raw material inflation occurs. So I feel confident that customers want to continue to buy from us, and we need to pass on those costs. And I think folks understand that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the RIS business, you have indicated that it looked like there was a little bit of restocking, there was some inventory or there would be some restocking coming, inventories look like they were relatively light throughout your customer chan
componenttext: With regard to the RIS business, you have indicated that it looked like there was a little bit of restocking, there was some inventory or there would be some restocking coming, inventories look like they were relatively light throughout your customer channel. And at the same time, you indicated that the back-to-school season might be coming later than expected. The two don't exactly jibe. So what gives you confidence that the back-to-school season does come later than expected and doesn't hit in the second quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the first one, obviously, RIS is driven apparel. The inventory-to-sales ratio for apparel dropped to its lowest level ever, at least in our charts in a number of years in February. So at the same time, I think March apparel sales actually rebounded qui
componenttext: So the first one, obviously, RIS is driven apparel. The inventory-to-sales ratio for apparel dropped to its lowest level ever, at least in our charts in a number of years in February. So at the same time, I think March apparel sales actually rebounded quite nicely. I think we're starting to see some restocking. Frankly, what we're saying anecdotally is retailers giving us a forecast of X and then saying when they actually order, saying, "Oh no, it's X plus 15 or X plus 20." So my sense is that in the U.S. for U.S. retailers and brand owners, there's a lot more confidence. And so we're feeling pretty good about the trends. Let's say that the apparel is kind of one of those low-cost luxuries. And as consumers get a little more confident buying that extra outfit isn't huge. Back-to-school is all about binders and dividers for us. And so the two are necessarily linked. I got to tell you, every other year it's the same. One year, it's early; the next year, it's late. We actually know, though, from a couple of customers who want their back-to-school season to run a little later and longer that we just simply expect the orders to flow through a little more in the third quarter than the second quarter. However, it's always tough to predict. They could change their minds in the next two weeks, and we just don't know.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think specific to your question, the restocking that Dean refers to is primarily going on in RIS in the apparel space. The delay in back-to-school is in the office space.
componenttext: I think specific to your question, the restocking that Dean refers to is primarily going on in RIS in the apparel space. The delay in back-to-school is in the office space.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, yes, I think I misunderstood. I thought you were in the RIS segment as well.
componenttext: That's helpful, yes, I think I misunderstood. I thought you were in the RIS segment as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, sorry, yes. There is a back-to-school apparel season as well obviously and the fall season. And that's basically what's happening right now. And my sense there is that retailers, again, are chasing orders. And they need to get their inventories topped
componenttext: No, sorry, yes. There is a back-to-school apparel season as well obviously and the fall season. And that's basically what's happening right now. And my sense there is that retailers, again, are chasing orders. And they need to get their inventories topped off a little bit what they have before. When you add that to the positive demand that we're seeing, I think RIS will obviously have a much better year than last year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question is just in the Office Products area, with regard to your investing in it and trying to defend, I guess, relative to some new competition in the space. How long do you think this plays out in terms of some of the incremental margin pressures
componenttext: Last question is just in the Office Products area, with regard to your investing in it and trying to defend, I guess, relative to some new competition in the space. How long do you think this plays out in terms of some of the incremental margin pressures you may be feeling? It seems like the competitor that's pushing into the market is pretty big, has brand awareness as well. So I mean, how should we think about this playing out in terms of the margins over the, say, next say next year or two?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think a year or two is about right. I think we've got a number of new application in product areas that we've been doing a lot of qualitative and quantitative research in. And we'll be launching some new products at the end of this year. But most of the
componenttext: I think a year or two is about right. I think we've got a number of new application in product areas that we've been doing a lot of qualitative and quantitative research in. And we'll be launching some new products at the end of this year. But most of the activity on new products will likely really hit in 2011. And also, we feel good in the test markets that we've had versus our competitor in spaces we've done quite well. So I guess maybe the real answer is as long as it takes to defend the category, we're confident we'll be successful.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Joe Naya from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Joe Naya from UBS.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I realize that this is just a broad scenario. But looking back when you gave in your fourth quarter results, you're looking at a scenario with a 5% organic sales increase driving a $2.70 to $3 EPS number versus the $2.50 to $2.80 where we are now. It seem
componenttext: I realize that this is just a broad scenario. But looking back when you gave in your fourth quarter results, you're looking at a scenario with a 5% organic sales increase driving a $2.70 to $3 EPS number versus the $2.50 to $2.80 where we are now. It seems though inflation is probably the biggest mover there. But are there any other issues that we should be thinking about in terms of that change?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The two factors are the ones that we talked about, inflation and our ability to catch up with that through pricing is the single biggest change. As I mentioned, we've seen twice as much inflation on its way to us as we had anticipated coming into the year
componenttext: The two factors are the ones that we talked about, inflation and our ability to catch up with that through pricing is the single biggest change. As I mentioned, we've seen twice as much inflation on its way to us as we had anticipated coming into the year. And the other is the effort to grow and defend at the same time in the Office Products space that's hitting margins a bit. So those are the reasons. Sales will be strong, we still have a good earnings growth, but we'll going to have some margin pressure.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you're planning to probably invest a little bit more now than you were back when you reported fourth quarter?
componenttext: So you're planning to probably invest a little bit more now than you were back when you reported fourth quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You bet.
componenttext: You bet.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I apologize if I missed this, but did you give kind of the 1Q, the inflation impact in 1Q?
componenttext: I apologize if I missed this, but did you give kind of the 1Q, the inflation impact in 1Q?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We weren't specific about it. No, I haven't done that. We quantified what will hit us for the year. And that hits us primarily through the first two and into the third quarter. We'll still have some inflation coming in the third quarter as well based on w
componenttext: We weren't specific about it. No, I haven't done that. We quantified what will hit us for the year. And that hits us primarily through the first two and into the third quarter. We'll still have some inflation coming in the third quarter as well based on what our suppliers are indicating to us.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had some inflation in the fourth quarter recall. So we caught up with some of that inflation in Q1, although we did see additional inflation in Q1 as well.
componenttext: We had some inflation in the fourth quarter recall. So we caught up with some of that inflation in Q1, although we did see additional inflation in Q1 as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of your expectation for uses of cash, you mentioned potentially returning some cash to shareholders. But could you just kind of refresh us on your priorities and if you have any expectations in terms of debt paydown as well?
componenttext: And then just in terms of your expectation for uses of cash, you mentioned potentially returning some cash to shareholders. But could you just kind of refresh us on your priorities and if you have any expectations in terms of debt paydown as well?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the first priority remains debt paydown, based on the cash flow forecast we've provided for the year, late in the year, we'll achieve our debt targets, and at that time, start thinking about the dividend. So the board looks at the dividend eve
componenttext: Sure. Well, the first priority remains debt paydown, based on the cash flow forecast we've provided for the year, late in the year, we'll achieve our debt targets, and at that time, start thinking about the dividend. So the board looks at the dividend every quarter. Our current discussions would indicate some willingness to start moving cash back to shareholders because we'll hit those debt targets later in the year. So we obviously cut the dividend last year. We'd like to see the dividend start moving back up in the direction where we head at pre-recession, and that will be the discussion. But we intend to look at share repurchases as well. We have another round, the final round of our converts, that come due late this year. So there's a couple million shares that we'll issue. We would like to not see those additional shares outstanding for very long, but debt comes first.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Peter Ruschmeier from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Peter Ruschmeier from Barclays Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could help us better understand the improvement in the margins. You mentioned 410 basis points PSM margin improvement year-over-year. It was 250 basis points sequentially. How much of that margin improvement would you attribute to the 8%
componenttext: I was hoping you could help us better understand the improvement in the margins. You mentioned 410 basis points PSM margin improvement year-over-year. It was 250 basis points sequentially. How much of that margin improvement would you attribute to the 8% organic volume growth versus other factors?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's about a third of the total came from a volume. We still are carrying year-on-year much of the benefit of price increases that were happening a year ago that caught us up with the last round of inflation. So still, as we came into the first quarter, t
componenttext: It's about a third of the total came from a volume. We still are carrying year-on-year much of the benefit of price increases that were happening a year ago that caught us up with the last round of inflation. So still, as we came into the first quarter, the net of price and raw material was a positive year-on-year, but about a third was volume and the rest was restructuring and productivity that we drove as the year went by.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Shifting to the RFID opportunity. You mentioned increased item-level marking interest. I'm curious if you can further elaborate on what you're seeing from customers, what types of applications, what types of customers, what types of geographies are you se
componenttext: Shifting to the RFID opportunity. You mentioned increased item-level marking interest. I'm curious if you can further elaborate on what you're seeing from customers, what types of applications, what types of customers, what types of geographies are you seeing the increased interest?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've seen it kind of across the board, to be honest, both in industrial applications. But certainly in retail for item-level marking, there's been the highest level of interest we've ever experienced. And we're definitely going to see a ramp up in
componenttext: Well, we've seen it kind of across the board, to be honest, both in industrial applications. But certainly in retail for item-level marking, there's been the highest level of interest we've ever experienced. And we're definitely going to see a ramp up in the back half of the year as we implement a couple of key programs. And I anticipate, actually, it's sort of our highest scenario level, we may have to actually increase our capital budget to debt internally, not externally at this point. And that can serve capacity because I think we're close to a tipping point in item-level marking for RFID, and we'll see. We've been kind of there before. But there's a lot more serious discussion about this technology from a lot of retailers.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Dean, what kind of investment is required from your customers? Are these large customers or small customers? Are these large capital investments to enable the technology? Can you elaborate on that?
componenttext: And Dean, what kind of investment is required from your customers? Are these large customers or small customers? Are these large capital investments to enable the technology? Can you elaborate on that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It depends on the retail recourse. But it's in anywhere from $5,000 to $15,000 to $20,000 per store in terms of investment. In terms of the readers and the other devices required to read from a capital perspective. Of course, it changes the consumables co
componenttext: It depends on the retail recourse. But it's in anywhere from $5,000 to $15,000 to $20,000 per store in terms of investment. In terms of the readers and the other devices required to read from a capital perspective. Of course, it changes the consumables cost as well. And you're taking a tag that cost $0.02 and your making the cost to $0.10. There is an investment there. But the business case is solid in terms of reduced inventory, increased sales from having products in stock, and the balance between those two is actually what retailers are focused a lot on right now. So it's happening.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And not to cut this to finally, but do you think your customers have already budgeted for these types of expenditures or do you think they're just closer to the edge of pulling the trigger on allocating capital for these kinds of expenditures?
componenttext: And not to cut this to finally, but do you think your customers have already budgeted for these types of expenditures or do you think they're just closer to the edge of pulling the trigger on allocating capital for these kinds of expenditures?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Some have definitely allocated capital and are moving forward, and others are still in the decision phase. And I believe we'll see some rollouts in the back half of this year, starting in the back half of this year. This usually take a number of quarters
componenttext: Some have definitely allocated capital and are moving forward, and others are still in the decision phase. And I believe we'll see some rollouts in the back half of this year, starting in the back half of this year. This usually take a number of quarters to roll out, especially if it's a large store chain. And certainly in 2011, we'll see some increased interest as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we look at your performance over the years and method against EVA per share. And I think you've seen this as well, there's a very, very strong correlation between the net economic profit you generate and what it means for the stock price and relative
componenttext: When we look at your performance over the years and method against EVA per share. And I think you've seen this as well, there's a very, very strong correlation between the net economic profit you generate and what it means for the stock price and relative performance. And we've seen, obviously, recovery in both over the last year as you pull back on spending and generated more cash. Given the investments that you need to make in Office Products and some of the things you're hinting at with RFID and maybe other areas, what confidence should we have that you can continue to drive economic profit higher from here? Or maybe should we expect given what you're looking at right now, maybe a plateau until you reach another ramp later on in the decade?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we've got the bar set pretty low frankly right now, George. So I feel very confident moving forward. Our business has generated great free cash flow. We've used a lot of that free cash flow to invest in restructuring over the past two years, as we
componenttext: I think we've got the bar set pretty low frankly right now, George. So I feel very confident moving forward. Our business has generated great free cash flow. We've used a lot of that free cash flow to invest in restructuring over the past two years, as well as more recently, paying down debt. Now I believe we're going to get a situation now where we won't need the cash for restructuring. But we'll use some of that cash to invest in growth, organic growth, and we'll still have plenty of cash to return to shareholders and keep our debt-to-equity balance right on target. So it's low-risk spending, I guess, is what I would put and more high-quality spending in terms of the returns we get. We expect to get top line growth with good returns.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this juncture that we look at, should we still expect that RIS is the biggest driver of the improvement in returns from where like this last quarter, it's Pressure-Sensitive Materials is still the horse that drives the train?
componenttext: At this juncture that we look at, should we still expect that RIS is the biggest driver of the improvement in returns from where like this last quarter, it's Pressure-Sensitive Materials is still the horse that drives the train?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Pressure-Sensitive Materials is the core business of the company, and we are making some investments for growth in that business as well. I do expect it to continue to generate good solid growth, top line, bottom line and free cash flow. That's a gr
componenttext: Well, Pressure-Sensitive Materials is the core business of the company, and we are making some investments for growth in that business as well. I do expect it to continue to generate good solid growth, top line, bottom line and free cash flow. That's a great business. And with our investments in end-use marketing now, we really are building on an interesting and excellent pipeline of needs from a number of end-use sectors. That being said, from a relative basis, RIS has the most upside simply because of its current performance level and what we believe this business can do. So I also believe that RIS given it's -- it's got the cost out, we're still going to continue to do that. We have growth opportunities on both the branded solutions side, but as well as the information solutions side, especially if item-level -- if item-level RFID takes off, it brings a whole new trajectory to that business.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: With RIS, do we get to the types of margins that we could have calculated based on where the business is pre-recession, the restructuring that was done and so on, at $1.4 billion, $1.5 billion? Or do you really need to get back to like $1.6 billion of rev
componenttext: With RIS, do we get to the types of margins that we could have calculated based on where the business is pre-recession, the restructuring that was done and so on, at $1.4 billion, $1.5 billion? Or do you really need to get back to like $1.6 billion of revenue within that segment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We need more rapid growth, and we need more growth productivity to get to the margin targets that we had. So it's not going to happen instantaneously for sure. And I don't want to get into your formula, but I still have a strong belief that this business,
componenttext: We need more rapid growth, and we need more growth productivity to get to the margin targets that we had. So it's not going to happen instantaneously for sure. And I don't want to get into your formula, but I still have a strong belief that this business, it will be an important contributor to economic profit for the corporation going forward.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Speakers, we have no further questions at this time. You may resume at your presentation or closing remarks.
componenttext: Speakers, we have no further questions at this time. You may resume at your presentation or closing remarks.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, just to sum up, we're more confident, certainly than January that an economic recovery will continue through the year. Although raw material inflation will be a bit of a challenge with short-term margin pressure, I want to emphasize short-term, not
componenttext: Okay, just to sum up, we're more confident, certainly than January that an economic recovery will continue through the year. Although raw material inflation will be a bit of a challenge with short-term margin pressure, I want to emphasize short-term, not long-term. And over time, we do expect our pricing to catch up with inflation. We talked about Office Products and the reason for setting up investment there. And we're planning offense across the company in a number of our sectors to capitalize on opportunities for growth. We just talked about RIS, and I expect this business with its high contribution margins to expand margin significantly as revenue grows. And our Pressure-Sensitive and other businesses have increased upside as end-user marketing initiatives pay off and we get the full benefit of our restructuring program. Our actions will continue to increase sales, operating leverage and earnings power for the company. And on behalf of all of us, thanks to everyone for joining, and we look forward to speaking with you again.
