componenttextpreview: Here’s the external metrics, John. Inventory-to-sales ratio for apparel and soft goods, which I think we’ve published from time to time, so it’s a publicly available document. I’m going to be watching back-to-school sales really closely. Now, that
componenttext: Here’s the external metrics, John. Inventory-to-sales ratio for apparel and soft goods, which I think we’ve published from time to time, so it’s a publicly available document. I’m going to be watching back-to-school sales really closely. Now, that doesn’t tell you much for the current quarter, but it does tell you what retailers are likely to do in the next quarter. Last year was a really tough year. Sales should improve year-over-year for Retail Information Services, so you’ll definitely be able to gauge the flow-through. It will not be as high as it was from a nominal level as the second quarter. You’ll get to compare year-over-year is really my point.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the other things we look at is just over 2008 levels and just tracking what the overall growth rate and trends are versus 2008, because that was more normalized. Q4 dropped off a little bit, but 2008 was a much more normalized period, so that
componenttext: Yes. One of the other things we look at is just over 2008 levels and just tracking what the overall growth rate and trends are versus 2008, because that was more normalized. Q4 dropped off a little bit, but 2008 was a much more normalized period, so that would be something to look to for overall traction.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Then in additional spending in Office Products, it’s easy to understand the promotional activities being done, what are the innovation spending that’s going on there? Where is that targeted?
componenttext: Then in additional spending in Office Products, it’s easy to understand the promotional activities being done, what are the innovation spending that’s going on there? Where is that targeted?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we launched some new products late last year, our NoteTabs and Label Pads, which are doing quite well by the way, and we’re pleased with that. They’re doing quite well with no advertising. So we’re excited about some of the demand creation tha
componenttext:
Well, we launched some new products late last year, our NoteTabs and Label Pads, which are doing quite well by the way, and we’re pleased with that. They’re doing quite well with no advertising. So we’re excited about some of the demand creation that we’ll be implementing actually starting next week.
The other innovation, frankly, it’s pretty straight forward. So our target consumer uses our products in the office a lot, but there are other verticals where our brand is relevant and we just have not spend a lot of time or energy coming up with products that we can use in the home or in schools and on the people that are mobile workers.
What we found through quite a bit of market research late last year and early this year that there are solutions that we can offer, where the Avery brand is incredibly relevant and can get sell-through our existing channels and distribution. So we’ll be launching a number of new products. We’re still in market tests with some exciting things which I can’t really talk about yet that will start to show up in really about the first quarter of 2011. So that does cost some money, but we’re excited to do it because I believe that we’ll begin to change the sales trajectory of this business.

componenttextpreview: Well, as you can imagine, this has been the focus of that organization’s efforts over the past year. So we feel good about our current distribution. We had just recently negotiated with a number of our customers over the past six months. As I said, at o
componenttext: Well, as you can imagine, this has been the focus of that organization’s efforts over the past year. So we feel good about our current distribution. We had just recently negotiated with a number of our customers over the past six months. As I said, at one retailer we lost not all of our distribution but we kept all of our commercial distribution, which in this case happened to 60% commercial. In retail, we lost all about our 15 top SKUs, which I consider to be kind of a victory in a way. I mean, that customer basically said, well, we still need your top SKUs in the store. Our customers are going to demand that they be there. So far it’s limited in terms of that, and I think the plans for the stores are pretty much set for the balance of the year.

componenttextpreview: I thought I heard you say earlier regarding Pressure-Sensitive that you have some new technologies and approaches that you’re bringing to the market, could you give us a bit more clarity on what exactly are you thinking about and should we see more deta

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely post-Labelexpo, you’ll see that. We’ve got a couple of new products. We have a product that allows our end users to get more surface area in printing on contort containers. So think of a shrink film, it has got pressure-sensitive chara
componenttext:
Yes, definitely post-Labelexpo, you’ll see that. We’ve got a couple of new products. We have a product that allows our end users to get more surface area in printing on contort containers. So think of a shrink film, it has got pressure-sensitive characteristics, but also has clear characteristics at the same time. So customers that have seen that product like it a lot, because right now you have this binary choice, which is, I use pressure-sensitive on the one hand and I can decorate a part of a container, but if I use shrink-sleeve, I’ve got to decorate the whole container, and by the way, it’s opaque. There’s no really clear shrink-sleeve today that can be used.
So what we’re offering up is an attractive alternative. It requires a change in the application technology, which we’ve partnered with an outside company to do, and that’s a big deal, and we’re in the process of starting up a couple of new application that’ll be online I think by the end of the year. So that’s pretty exciting. That’s one example.

componenttext: George, I don’t want to anticipate your follow-on, but we hope everyone noticed on the slide, the tax rate, that we’ve moved that, we’ve made the comment that that should be at the high end of the range. So it’s just traditionally been in the lower end of it, and now for the full year probably in the high end of it.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I’d just like to say we’re very confident about our future. It was a real solid quarter and I was really pleased with the traction that we gained in the Retail Information Services business and certainly the promise of radio frequency item
componenttext:
Okay. Well, I’d just like to say we’re very confident about our future. It was a real solid quarter and I was really pleased with the traction that we gained in the Retail Information Services business and certainly the promise of radio frequency item level marking really come out, we’ve been talking about that for the last couple of quarters that we really do see this as the future and it’s obviously one of the key reasons that we made the Paxar acquisition.
I’m also happy with Pressure-Sensitive Materials. They had a great quarter. We have been investing in more demand creation through our marketing and end-use activity, and that’s starting to pay off. And with Office Products, we got a little bit more of an uphill battle, but you’ll start to see some of the demand creation activities on some of our current products, and then in 2011, many new products that we plan to introduce in that space.
We do face some near-term challenges between currency and raw material issues and the price gap, as well as some of the investments on Office Products, but I just want to make the point again, especially on the raw material margin issues, I do not see that as a long-term issue. I just see it as a transitional issue too. One of two things happen, we either get prices up or raw material costs will start to plateau and hopefully in a couple of places go again. So thanks for listening and we look forward to speaking with you next quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Avery Dennison Corp. Quarterly Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, October 27, 2010. I would now like to turn the confere
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Avery Dennison Corp. Quarterly Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, October 27, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Eric Leeds. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with a slide presentation titled Third Quarter 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and po
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with a slide presentation titled Third Quarter 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. We remind you that results are preliminary as we have not yet filed our 10-Q.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes interest expense, restructuring and other charges included in the other expense line of our P&L. Restructuring charges tend to be fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing.
In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on pre-tax results before their effect and before interest expense. These numbers are reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release.
We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we provided today, along with our 2009 Form 10-K and 2010 Forms 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations.
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Cindy Guenther, Vice President, Global Financial Planning and Analysis.
I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. This is our third consecutive quarter of strong top line growth, driven by our largest segments, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services. Sales of both segments were above prerecession levels
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. This is our third consecutive quarter of strong top line growth, driven by our largest segments, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services. Sales of both segments were above prerecession levels with volume growth in all regions and continued strength in emerging markets. As we expected, margins came under pressure as raw material inflation outpaced price increases, resulting in a decline in margins year-over-year. We saw additional cost increases in late Q3, and as a result, have announced additional price increases in the fourth quarter.
Pressure-sensitive Materials delivered solid sales growth though with lower margins sequentially and year-over-year. This is where the inflation has hit us the hardest. Raw material strength in emerging markets and its focus on end customers contributed to high single-digit sales growth, while Graphics and Reflectives saw also double-digit growth especially in cast films and reflective materials. 
I recently attended Labelexpo and had the opportunity to talk with many of our customers. The overall mood was positive. Most converters indicated that business was good, although somewhat choppy, meaning that their order books were strong for a few weeks and then would pause. My takeaway is that end users are still reluctant to add inventory and are ordering very close to their demand levels. Converters indicated there were still quite a bit of quoting and new product activity, and customer optimism was demonstrated by robust press and equipment sales during the show.
We showcased several innovative technologies at Labelexpo. One is an ultra-thin liner material called Thin Stream that enabled less waste and lowered total applied cost. This innovation is targeted at the food and beverage market segment where pressure-sensitive penetration is low. The second innovation is Fasson curve appeal, which will enable consumer packaged goods companies to label containers with complex curves where today the only option is shrink sleeves. Both of these new proprietary solutions are in the early stages of commercialization, but are great examples of our new innovation platform.
I was very pleased with our progress in Retail Information Services. Our service improvement and our capability to offer a sustainable and brand-enhancing solution, along with supply chain and Information Solutions to major retailers and brands drove 18% sales growth in the quarter. Sales volumes, combined with a solid productivity, enabled solid year-over-year profit growth. RFID item-level marketing continues to gain traction. Sales of these products more than doubled in the quarter.
Office and Consumer Products results were as expected. Sales during back-to-school season, which runs from May through September, were flat year-over-year at point-of-sale, and our shipments were down slightly overall as retailers managed inventory down. While we did lose some share in the labels category, I'm encouraged by the sales of our new products such as label pads and note tabs. We continue to make progress this quarter on the top line and despite greater-than-expected raw material inflation, we expect to achieve the upper end of the annual guidance range that we provided in April. 
Now Mitch will give you a more detailed explanation of the quarter and the full year outlook.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking to the Slide 8. Sales in the third quarter were up organically about 8%. As Dean mentioned, we again experienced strong volume growth in our 2 largest segments with Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail In
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking to the Slide 8. Sales in the third quarter were up organically about 8%. As Dean mentioned, we again experienced strong volume growth in our 2 largest segments with Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services delivering solid growth in all regions. The growth in these segments continues to more than offset the revenue decline in office products. 
As expected, our operating margin declined 6.5% in the third quarter as the benefit of higher volume was more than offset by rising raw material costs, higher employee-related costs and increased investment and growth in infrastructure. Now while our operating margin was in line with expenses for the quarter, we are experiencing additional pressure in raw materials as Dean mentioned. Raw material costs continue to rise, and we now expect total raw material inflation to be approximately $105 million for the full year. That's $10 million more than when we last spoke to you. 
The pressure in raw material costs continue to be driven by capacity constraints for certain adhesive components and paper liners. Given this new round of inflation, we are announcing additional pricing increases. These are in addition to the increases we've just implemented in the third quarter. We've previously said that we anticipate a closing in the price inflation gap by the end of the year. We now expect we will only be able to narrow it by year end, and we'll not close the gap until early in 2011. This, of course, assumes no additional raw material inflation.
Turning to Slide 9. Our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment again delivered strong organic revenue growth of 9%, although on lower margins of 8.3%. The growth was driven by continued solid performance in all regions of our raw material business with particularly strong growth continuing in our emerging markets. Specifically, North America is up mid-single digits, Western Europe was up high single digits and the emerging markets were up in the mid-teens. 
Sequentially, the operating margin for this segment declined 130 basis points as this segment is experiencing the vast majority of the raw material inflation. Retail Information Services delivered even stronger organic growth of 18% on higher operating margins. Third quarter revenue comps benefited from significant inventory destocking in the prior year, as well as improved retail apparel sales and new programs with key brands and retailers. While July and August retail inventory-to-sales ratios are off of the March bottom, they remain close to historically record lows. This is all the more reason why we're pleased with RIS' revenue in the third quarter. We are also pleased with the continuing margin expansion in RIS. Operating margins increased 5.6 percentage points in the third quarter, primarily due to volume. The sequential decline in RIS' margin is reflective of the normal seasonal sales trend. So RIS continues to show its operating leverage on the upside on track to double-digit margins.
Looking at Office Products. The decline in sales in the third quarter reflected weak end market demand and increased competition in the labeled portion of this business. Office Products operating margin declined in the quarter due to increased consumer promotion, demand creation and investment innovation, as well as lower volumes. We previously discussed the competitive situation in this segment, so our margins will remain under pressure here while we continue to invest and defend. For this year, that means Office Products is expected to deliver low double-digit margin.
Our other specialty converting businesses had solid sales growth on lower margins. These businesses were also adversely impacted by the significant raw material inflation we discussed earlier. And it's the primary driver of the decline in the operating margin.
Now moving on to guidance on Slides 12 and 13. Just as we did last quarter, we've highlighted the key factors in our current guidance assumptions that are different from what we said in July. Based on the factors listed, as well as other assumptions, we now expect reported revenue growth of 9%, adjusted EPS of $3.70 to $3.20 per share and free cash flow of $350 million to $375 million. 
We are expecting a discrete tax planning event in the fourth quarter that is expected to add approximately $0.40 of EPS this year, and we'll reduce taxes we expect to pay in future years. While this benefit will reduce our effective tax rate this year, we continue to expect an ongoing tax rate of 20% to 24%. This benefit is the primary reason why our guidance is up from last quarter. Excluding this expected tax event, full year 2010 adjusted EPS guidance would be $2.70 to $2.80, which reflects the higher end of our previous range. 
To highlight a couple of the other key changes in our assumptions, I mentioned the $105 million of inflation, which is up from our previous forecast of $95 million. At current rates, currency is now expected to be neutral to the P&L, and we may make pension contributions greater than $50 million. The actual amount we choose to contribute depends on where free cash flow is ending up in the December time frame. 
On the subject of pensions, I do want to note that we announced that we will freeze our U.S. defined benefit plan at the end of the year. The effect of this change is reflected in the financial statements, including a modest curtailment charge. We expect this will modestly reduce our pension expense, but increase our pension contributions in 2011. We will provide more information on the effect of this change of 2011 when we provide 2011 guidance early next year.
Before opening the call to questions, I do want to comment on our increased financial strength. As many of you know, mid-last year, we began a program to aggressively reduce our debt. We're exceeding our stated goals. We've reduced our debt by a more than $400 million since we embarked on this program mid-last year. And our net debt to EBITDA ratio is down significantly and now approximately 2, a key milestone. This is a significant improvement in the financial strength, driven by both higher profits and less debt. 
Now we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: On the PSM business, as we look at the first quarter and second quarter operating margins, they were just under 10%. 3Q was obviously pressured by higher raw material costs, and just based on your comments, it looks like that we should -- margin should push higher directionally into 4Q and also higher into 1Q. But do you still feel though that as we perhaps look at the rest of '11 and assuming no new inflation that 10% operating is still the right level of operating margins for that business?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ghansham, this is Dean. Our long-term target hasn't changed. We think that the Pressure-sensitive Materials sector should operate in the 10% to 12% operating margin range. We're not giving guidance for 2011, but I also expect us to catch up on some o
componenttext: Yes, Ghansham, this is Dean. Our long-term target hasn't changed. We think that the Pressure-sensitive Materials sector should operate in the 10% to 12% operating margin range. We're not giving guidance for 2011, but I also expect us to catch up on some of this inflation in the fourth quarter as our price increases begin to catch up with the additional inflation we're seeing. The big question for me is when will the inflation start to curtail? And we just don't know yet.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you look at trends on PSM for both 2Q and 3Q, did 2Q benefit from some sort of pre-buying ahead of your price increases?
componenttext: Okay. And then as you look at trends on PSM for both 2Q and 3Q, did 2Q benefit from some sort of pre-buying ahead of your price increases?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we rarely see that in this business especially these days because customers as I talk to customers, they basically are seeing their customers are ordering just as a rate of demand. So everybody's being quite cautious about building inventory. So I don
componenttext: No, we rarely see that in this business especially these days because customers as I talk to customers, they basically are seeing their customers are ordering just as a rate of demand. So everybody's being quite cautious about building inventory. So I don't see any changes in the customer behavior trying to build inventory in advance of price increases.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just one final one on cash flow just based on Mitch's last comments. Obviously, free cash flow has improved considerably. Your debt position's improved quite a bit as well. Understand that maybe too early to qualify to sort of think about a dividend i
componenttext: And just one final one on cash flow just based on Mitch's last comments. Obviously, free cash flow has improved considerably. Your debt position's improved quite a bit as well. Understand that maybe too early to qualify to sort of think about a dividend increase just based on the cut last year, but what's the board's appetite on meaningful slug of share buybacks?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the board, and we said this, I think we said this last quarter. We certainly talk to investors that the board was us to get the year "in the can," in other words, put to bed. We are certainly feeling good about our financial position, and our desire
componenttext: Well, the board, and we said this, I think we said this last quarter. We certainly talk to investors that the board was us to get the year "in the can," in other words, put to bed. We are certainly feeling good about our financial position, and our desire is to return more cash to shareholders. And I am feeling pretty good about -- we'll use both potential dividend increases and share buyback as a way to return more cash to shareholders. That will very likely happen in 2011.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Silke Kueck for Jeff. A couple of questions. In RIS, it seemed that if I remember the trends quarterly, it seemed that July was sort of more sluggish in August too and then September really picked up. And the indications now that because normally
componenttext: This is Silke Kueck for Jeff. A couple of questions. In RIS, it seemed that if I remember the trends quarterly, it seemed that July was sort of more sluggish in August too and then September really picked up. And the indications now that because normally it's a seasonal step up from the third quarter to fourth quarter that the fourth quarter could be really large. Where is it the case that there was some forward selling in September from the fourth quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a complex question to answer, but I'll take a crack at it. One of the issues that's happening in the supply chain for apparel this year is that there's been a pretty large bottleneck of getting goods out of South China for a number of reasons. And
componenttext: That's a complex question to answer, but I'll take a crack at it. One of the issues that's happening in the supply chain for apparel this year is that there's been a pretty large bottleneck of getting goods out of South China for a number of reasons. And so the seasonality this year has been changed a bit. So the third quarter I think came in a little stronger because of goods coming in late that normally would have come in the second quarter. I will say that the order trends early in the fourth quarter and late in the third quarter have continued to be positive for us, and I attribute that to our service levels. We've captured some new programs, and the fact that the inventory-to-sales ratio in apparel is still relatively low. So I still remains cautiously optimistic about the business going forward.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But we don't expect necessarily the high teens to be the trend going into Q4 year-over-year growth for the reasons of the shift in timing of the counter this year because of the bottlenecks being talked about.
componenttext: But we don't expect necessarily the high teens to be the trend going into Q4 year-over-year growth for the reasons of the shift in timing of the counter this year because of the bottlenecks being talked about.

componenttext: It's hard to predict. We don't want to give any specific segment expectations overall for the quarter. But overall, you would expect Q2 to be the strongest within this business, and fourth quarter is the second strongest, followed by the third and then the first quarters. You would not expect I would say for the reasons Dean commented on the third quarter did not drop off as much as normal and so therefore, we wouldn't expect the fourth quarter to bounce back quite as strong.

componenttext: But you still expect the fourth quarter to be better than the third?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm sorry. That makes it clear. In terms of raw materials, are the pressures that you have seen due to some shortages maybe in acrylics, can you mitigate this somehow by purchasing globally? And do you expect the tightness to continue or will it sor
componenttext: Okay. I'm sorry. That makes it clear. In terms of raw materials, are the pressures that you have seen due to some shortages maybe in acrylics, can you mitigate this somehow by purchasing globally? And do you expect the tightness to continue or will it sort of like moderate into next year? Maybe you can comment like whether you have the opportunities to purchase more regionally.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we do purchase globally, and I think our team has done a terrific job at making sure we stayed in supply. In fact, and some of the reason that it cost us a little money is that we went out on these spot market a bit early and made sure we had source
componenttext: Well, we do purchase globally, and I think our team has done a terrific job at making sure we stayed in supply. In fact, and some of the reason that it cost us a little money is that we went out on these spot market a bit early and made sure we had sources of supply. A couple of our competitors had put certain products on sales allocation for a while due to the shortages. So we did not have to do that. We didn't expect to see any deflation in the back half of the year from acrylic monomers, although the industry talk was, and what we've actually seen is an acceleration of cost increases rather than the other way. So I think in total, supply-demand situation gets in better balance. It's going to be continue to be tight. But we've got -- I think our team's done a good job on global sourcing to make sure that we have secure supply sources for.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just related to that, how much price have you achieved today date than pressure sensitive? And what are you looking for in the fourth quarter? Or what's the price increase that you're going out with?
componenttext: And just related to that, how much price have you achieved today date than pressure sensitive? And what are you looking for in the fourth quarter? Or what's the price increase that you're going out with?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, for example -- let me answer, and then Mitch will comment on how much price we have achieved. And we've announced a mid to high single-digit price increase in North America. And also in China, we've announced an increase in the mid-single digit rang
componenttext: Well, for example -- let me answer, and then Mitch will comment on how much price we have achieved. And we've announced a mid to high single-digit price increase in North America. And also in China, we've announced an increase in the mid-single digit range as well, and I know we're looking at this in other regions. As you might guess, given the U.S. dollar, the inflation tends to be more intense in dollar-denominated countries. So it's a pretty substantial price increase, but we need it. Our margins are really taking a hit because of the costs.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So overall, as far as the level of price increases, we are behind the curve and giving us that curve keeps accelerating on the raw material inflation. We keep adding -- do more price increases, but continue to behind our curve. And we don't expect to clos
componenttext: So overall, as far as the level of price increases, we are behind the curve and giving us that curve keeps accelerating on the raw material inflation. We keep adding -- do more price increases, but continue to behind our curve. And we don't expect to close it until early next year. If you ask within PSM, the amount for the price increase it depends what your starting point is overall. But we've recovered less than half, about 1/3 of the total inflation that we've seen in the third quarter relative to third quarter of last year within PSM.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And now we're facing an additional $10 million of incremental inflation in the fourth quarter, which we didn't see when we spoke with you 3 months ago, which we want everybody to remember. Silke, you mentioned the seasonality in RIS, and that could be mor
componenttext: And now we're facing an additional $10 million of incremental inflation in the fourth quarter, which we didn't see when we spoke with you 3 months ago, which we want everybody to remember. Silke, you mentioned the seasonality in RIS, and that could be more muted this year than in a normal year. But I think it's also important to remember the seasonality in Office Products. And the seasonality on Office Products would likely be magnified in a situation this year because BTS doesn't have a lot of the areas where we're experiencing the increased competition. And that could impact Office Products more in the fourth quarter as well.

And one of the other reasons for that other than just the timing of the ramp-up curve is RFID. So we do expect increased capital expenditures for our RFID next year relative to what we had this year.

componenttext: Okay. componenttextpreview: It really accelerated between the second quarter and the third quarter. And while we're seeing more in the fourth quarter, but as you can see it's $10 million incremental from what we previously thought. So it's roughly half. I don't have the specifics in
componenttext: It really accelerated between the second quarter and the third quarter. And while we're seeing more in the fourth quarter, but as you can see it's $10 million incremental from what we previously thought. So it's roughly half. I don't have the specifics in front of me, but it's roughly half you could expect to carryover mostly in the first half of the year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on your comments of RFID tracking sales having doubled. Can you remind us where you're tracking on an annualized run rate basis? And I guess related to this so I can tell we'll make this one question, what is the mood of your retail customers
componenttext: I'm curious on your comments of RFID tracking sales having doubled. Can you remind us where you're tracking on an annualized run rate basis? And I guess related to this so I can tell we'll make this one question, what is the mood of your retail customers in terms of their willingness to spend the capital needed to enable them to more aggressively use your tags?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the $50 million charges in total external sales for us and RFID-related items, we're still on track for that. We signed an additional agreement in the last quarter with a major retailer, who is implementing item-level tagging. Unfortunately, I can
componenttext: Yes. So the $50 million charges in total external sales for us and RFID-related items, we're still on track for that. We signed an additional agreement in the last quarter with a major retailer, who is implementing item-level tagging. Unfortunately, I can't say who they are. But there is an increasing appetite for implementing these programs across the industry. So the capital expense, frankly, isn't huge for a lot of these retailers, I mean, compared to what they're spending their money on today. So I'd consider it to be a real positive trend. The one point I want to make though is that the sales increases and the profit increases we're getting in RIS are barely impacted by current RFID item level. So we still have a lot of traction left in that business without RFID. And for me, RFID is really icing on the cake, and so it remains a good medium- to long-term upside for this business. But it's tracking along really well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if it's not much, capital on the customers' behalf, what is the pushback, if any, on why they're not embracing it more aggressively?
componenttext: And if it's not much, capital on the customers' behalf, what is the pushback, if any, on why they're not embracing it more aggressively?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's really there's 2 things. One is the changed management process. You have to change the way your processes work at the store and in your supply chain. And if you have 1,800 stores, that takes time to do. And the second thing is, of course, the increas
componenttext: It's really there's 2 things. One is the changed management process. You have to change the way your processes work at the store and in your supply chain. And if you have 1,800 stores, that takes time to do. And the second thing is, of course, the increase in consumables cost. So the price it could go from $0.01 to $0.02, $0.10 to $0.12. And that's an ongoing cost. There's clearly a payback and the benefit for that activity. But most retailers like to test the concept now in a number of product lines or the number of stores to gain confidence that they can execute, and then they tend to roll out.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a tax planning event that's occurring in a non-U.S. jurisdiction, and it's essentially coming in the form of a net operating loss as a result of some of the legal entity and restructuring that we've done throughout the year. And so that's being
componenttext: Sure. It's a tax planning event that's occurring in a non-U.S. jurisdiction, and it's essentially coming in the form of a net operating loss as a result of some of the legal entity and restructuring that we've done throughout the year. And so that's being triggered in the fourth quarter, and we'll recognize the benefit. It's noncash this year, and we're expecting to get the cash benefit in a few years' time.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up. In Office Products, if I remembered correctly, maybe the spend related to the spending of the competition office people was something like $5 million to $6 million this year. Does that still seem like the right number or do you expect to spend more?

componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure we gave specific numbers. Obviously, the label defense strategy is costing us some money. It was a very promotional quarter in terms of offering consumers discounts by both ourselves and our competitor. We incrementally though on an ann
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure we gave specific numbers. Obviously, the label defense strategy is costing us some money. It was a very promotional quarter in terms of offering consumers discounts by both ourselves and our competitor. We incrementally though on an annualized basis in terms of demand creation and innovation, it's about a $10 million to $15 million annualized spend. So that's the numbers we've been talking about.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, can you discuss the new Fasson products that's competitive with shrink-wrapped technologies, the Fasson Curve. Is that available on the market or when it will it come? And what are the initial sales look like?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, can you discuss the new Fasson products that's competitive with shrink-wrapped technologies, the Fasson Curve. Is that available on the market or when it will it come? And what are the initial sales look like?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the initial sales are pretty small. So we're in the process of commercializing this right now with a couple of end users. Basically, it's a combination of materials science and equipment that we've developed. And we're able to put, I guess you would
componenttext: Well, the initial sales are pretty small. So we're in the process of commercializing this right now with a couple of end users. Basically, it's a combination of materials science and equipment that we've developed. And we're able to put, I guess you would call it a shrinkable pressure-sensitive film on to complex curve products. And we're literally in the process. We'll have our first couple of installations in by the end of the year and in the first quarter. There's a high level of interest from our end users, especially in the health and beauty categories who want to use complex container shapes to differentiate themselves on the shelf. So a lot of work going on. It's not going to be material sales this year, probably not even next year. But it's a great example of innovation, and certainly it's a big door opener for us in a number of end-use customers.

componenttext: Yes, I just had a follow-up on some of the discussion around saffron. I think you said that because of the acrylic monomer situation and the way you manage it versus your competitors that they've put some of their customers on allocation. So I'm just wondering if that is sort of a global situation or just domestic? And did that allow you guys to pick up some share there contributing to the volume comp?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think the share -- we feel we've been gaining a little bit of share this year. We do not have the numbers for the third quarter. I don't know that it's resulted in much share gain, but I think it has resulted in customers' understanding the seriou
componenttext: I don't think the share -- we feel we've been gaining a little bit of share this year. We do not have the numbers for the third quarter. I don't know that it's resulted in much share gain, but I think it has resulted in customers' understanding the seriousness of the raw material situation. I think the sales allocations, if I remember correctly, really only occurred in the U.S. market. I'm not sure they occurred anywhere else, but I think it's getting a lot of support for the -- I guess it could happen in the EU as well. But it's more about customers start to worry more about supply than they do absolute price levels. So it's that situation.

componenttext: Jumped on the call late. If you've answered any of these already, I'm happy to take the answers offline. I guess the first question I had though, if you haven't covered it already, is where do you see the inventory levels for retail apparel relative to what you would hope to get to at the customers side and what would be the healthier level? And then I guess the second question would be how would you frame the incremental margin progress you saw in the business in the quarter relative to what your overall expectations would be and ultimately, your longer-term I guess 12% margin target?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the inventory-to-sales ratio, it's still near its historical lows for apparel and footwear. I don't expect it to decline a lot mainly because retailers are continuing to be cautious about how much inventory they put in stock. So they don't have to
componenttext: Yes, on the inventory-to-sales ratio, it's still near its historical lows for apparel and footwear. I don't expect it to decline a lot mainly because retailers are continuing to be cautious about how much inventory they put in stock. So they don't have to reduce it in terms of doing a lot of promotion. Back-to-school actually came in better than most retailers expected. It was late this year. I think that had more to do with the weather. And as I said earlier on the call, the early read on Q4 for us is quite nice. So I think we're sitting in a relatively good position in this business. In terms of the margin flow-through for Retail Information Services, they are exactly on track with what we expected.

componenttext: I had 2 follow ons, if I have the time for that. And then emerging markets, I'm not sure if you gave it or not, but what kind of profit growth have you seen in emerging markets? How large from a profit standpoint are your emerging market businesses now?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on Office Products, we didn't talk specifically about share. Actually in the third quarter was when we began to see the biggest magnitude of share loss because it wasn't until the beginning of the quarter that one of our retailers decided to displac
componenttext: Well, on Office Products, we didn't talk specifically about share. Actually in the third quarter was when we began to see the biggest magnitude of share loss because it wasn't until the beginning of the quarter that one of our retailers decided to displace many of our SKUs at retail. And so we lost in probably 6 to 8 share points in the quarter. It was actually less than we what expected, and that was the run rate coming out of the quarter actually. So we didn't lose that much share in the quarter, and so we did okay. And it was obviously a very promotional period for us. And that share loss obviously was just in the label category, which is 20% of our sales. So it's not across the board. The question around emerging markets, still those operating margins are higher than the company average, so growth is still strong in emerging markets. So that's definitely helped.

componenttext: Okay. Well, I'd like to thank everybody for joining the call today. And just to sum up, sales on our 2 largest segments are actually above 2008 levels and are more than offsetting the sales decline at Office Products. And although inflation pressured margins more than we anticipated, even with the additional inflation, we're on track to meet our year-end targets for earnings and free cash flow. So thanks, everyone, for joining, and we look forward to speaking with you again.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Avery Dennison Corporation Quarterly Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, October 27, 2010. I would now like to turn the c
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Avery Dennison Corporation Quarterly Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, Wednesday, October 27, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Eric Leeds. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Third Quarter 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone. Our discussion today will reference the earnings release that we issued earlier, along with the slide presentation titled Third Quarter 2010 Financial Review and Analysis. Both documents were furnished today with our 8-K and posted at the Investors section of our website at www.investors.averydennison.com. We remind you that these results are preliminary as we have not yet filed our 10-Q.
Our news release references GAAP operating margin, which includes interest expense, restructuring and other charges included in the other expense line of our P&L. Restructuring charges tend to be fairly disparate in amount, frequency and timing.
In light of the nature of these items, we'll focus our margin commentary on pretax results before their effect and before interest expense. These numbers are reconciled with GAAP in schedules A-2 to A-5 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release.
We also remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These statements are based on certain assumptions and expectations of future events that are subject to uncertainty. The Safe Harbor statement included in the documents that we provided today, along with our 2009 Form 10-K and 2010 Forms 10-Q, address certain risk factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations.
On the call today are Dean Scarborough, Chairman, President and CEO; Mitch Butier, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Cindy Guenther, Vice President, Global Financial Planning and Analysis.
I'll now turn the call over to Dean.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. This is our third consecutive quarter of strong top line growth, driven by our largest segments, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services. Sales of both segments were above pre-recession levels
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. This is our third consecutive quarter of strong top line growth, driven by our largest segments, Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services. Sales of both segments were above pre-recession levels with volume growth in all regions and continued strength in emerging markets. 
As we expected, margins came under pressure as raw material inflation outpaced price increases, resulting in a decline in margins year-over-year. We saw additional cost increases in late Q3, and as a result, have announced additional price increases in the fourth quarter.
Pressure-sensitive Materials delivered solid sales growth, though with lower margins sequentially and year-over-year. This is where the inflation has hit us the hardest. Raw material strength in emerging markets and a focus on end customers contributed to high single-digit sales growth, while Graphics and Reflective saw also double-digit growth especially in cast films and reflective materials. 
I recently attended Labelexpo and had the opportunity to talk with many of our customers. The overall mood was positive. Most converters indicated that business was good, although somewhat choppy, meaning that their order books were strong for a few weeks and then would pause. My takeaway is that end users are still reluctant to add inventory and are ordering very close to their demand levels. Converters indicated there were still quite a bit of quoting and new product activity, and customer optimism was demonstrated by robust press and equipment sales during the show.
We showcased several innovative technologies at Labelexpo. One is an ultra-thin liner material called ThinStream that enabled less waste and lower total applied cost. This innovation is targeted at the food and beverage market segment where pressure-sensitive penetration is low. 
The second innovation is Fasson Curve Appeal, which will enable consumer packaged goods companies to label containers with complex curves, where today the only option is shrink sleeves. Both of these new proprietary solutions are in the early stages of commercialization, but are great examples of our new innovation platform.
I was very pleased with our progress in Retail Information Services. Our service improvements and our capability to offer sustainable and brand-enhancing solution, along with supply chain and Information Solutions to major retailers and brands drove 18% sales growth in the quarter. Sales volumes, combined with solid productivity, enabled solid year-over-year profit growth. RFID item-level marking continues to gain traction. Sales of these products more than doubled in the quarter. 
Office and Consumer Products results were as expected. Sales during back-to-school season, which runs from May through September, were flat year-over-year at point-of-sale, and our shipments were down slightly, overall, as retailers managed inventories down. While we did lose some share in the labels category, I'm encouraged by the sales of our new products such as label pads and NoteTabs. 
We continued to make progress this quarter on the top line, and despite greater-than-expected raw material inflation, we expect to achieve the upper end of the annual guidance range that we provided in April. 
Now Mitch will give you a more detailed explanation of the quarter and the full year outlook.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking through to Slide 8. Sales in the third quarter were up organically about 8%. As Dean mentioned, we again experienced strong volume growth in our 2 largest segments, with Pressure-sensitive Materials and Reta
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Starting with Slide 5 and talking through to Slide 8. Sales in the third quarter were up organically about 8%. As Dean mentioned, we again experienced strong volume growth in our 2 largest segments, with Pressure-sensitive Materials and Retail Information Services delivering solid growth in all regions. The growth in these segments continues to more than offset the revenue decline in office products. 
As expected, our operating margin declined at 6.5% in the third quarter, as the benefit of higher volume was more than offset by rising raw material costs, higher employee-related costs and increased investments in growth and infrastructure. Now while our operating margin was in line with expectations for the quarter, we are experiencing additional pressure in raw materials, as Dean mentioned. Raw material costs continue to rise, and we now expect total raw material inflation to be approximately $105 million for the full year. That's $10 million more than when we last spoke to you. 
The pressure in raw material costs continues to be driven by capacity constraints for certain adhesive components and paper liners. Given this new round of inflation, we are announcing additional price increases. These are in addition to the increases we've just implemented in the third quarter. 
We previously said that we anticipated closing the price inflation gap by the end of the year. We now expect we will only be able to narrow it by year end, and we'll not close the gap until early in 2011. This, of course, assumes no additional raw material inflation.
Turning to Slide 9. Our Pressure-sensitive Materials segment again delivered strong organic revenue growth of 9%, although on lower margins of 8.3%. The growth was driven by continued solid performance in all regions of our raw material business with particularly strong growth continuing in our emerging markets. Specifically, North America is up mid-single digits, Western Europe was up high single digits and the emerging markets were up in the mid-teens. 
Sequentially, the operating margin for this segment declined 130 basis points, as this segment is experiencing the vast majority of the raw material inflation. Retail Information Services delivered even stronger organic growth of 18% on higher operating margins. Third quarter revenue comps benefited from significant inventory destocking of prior year, as well as improved retail apparel sales and new programs with key brands and retailers. 
While July and August retail inventory-to-sales ratios are off of the March bottom, they remain close to historically record lows. This is all the more reason why we're pleased with RIS' revenue in the third quarter. We are also pleased with the continuing margin expansion of RIS. Operating margins increased 5.6 percentage points in the third quarter, primarily due to volume. The sequential decline in RIS' margin is reflective of the normal seasonal sales trend. So RIS continues to show its operating leverage to the upside on track to double-digit margins.
Looking at Office Products, the decline in sales in the third quarter reflected weak end-market demand and increased competition in the labeled portion of this business. Office Products operating margin declined in the quarter due to increased consumer promotions, demand creation and investments in innovation, as well as lower volume. 
We previously discussed the competitive situation in this segment, so our margins will remain under pressure here while we continue to invest and defend. For this year, that means Office Products is expected to deliver low digit -- low double-digit margins. 
Our Other Specialty Converting businesses had solid sales growth on lower margins. These businesses were also adversely impacted by the significant raw material inflation we discussed earlier, and it's the primary driver of the decline in the operating margin.
Now moving on to guidance on Slides 12 and 13. Just as we did last quarter, we've highlighted the key factors in our current guidance assumptions that are different from what we said in July. Based on the factors listed, as well as other assumptions, we now expect reported revenue growth of 9%, adjusted EPS of $3.10 to $3.20 per share and free cash flow of $350 million to $375 million. 
We are expecting a discrete tax planning event in the fourth quarter that is expected to add approximately $0.40 of EPS this year, and we'll reduce taxes we expect to pay in future years. While this benefit will reduce our effective tax rate this year, we continue to expect an ongoing tax rate of 20% to 24%. This benefit is the primary reason why our guidance is up from last quarter. Excluding this expected tax event, full year 2010 adjusted EPS guidance would be $2.70 to $2.80, which reflects the higher end of our previous range. 
To highlight a couple of the other key changes in our assumptions, I mentioned the $105 million of inflation, which is up from our previous forecast of $95 million. At current rates, currency is now expected to be neutral to the P&L, and we may make pension contributions greater than $50 million. The actual amount we choose to contribute depends on where free cash flow is ending up in the December time frame. 
On the subject of pensions, I do want to note that we announced that we will freeze our U.S. defined benefit plan at the end of the year. The effect of this change is reflected in the financial statements including a modest curtailment charge. We expect this will modestly reduce our pension expense but increase our pension contributions in 2011. We will provide more information on the effect of this change in 2011 when we provide 2000 guidance -- 2011 guidance early next year.
Before opening the call to questions, I do want to comment on our increased financial strength. As many of you know, mid-last year, we began a program to aggressively reduce our debt. We're exceeding our stated goals. We have reduced our debt by a more than $400 million since we embarked on this program mid-last year, and our net debt to EBITDA ratio is down significantly and now approximately 2, a key milestone. This is a significant improvement in financial strength driven by both higher profits and less debt. 
Now we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the PSM business, as we look at the first quarter and second quarter operating margins, they were just under 10%. 3Q was obviously pressured by higher raw material costs. And just based on your comments, it looks like that we should -- margin should pu
componenttext: On the PSM business, as we look at the first quarter and second quarter operating margins, they were just under 10%. 3Q was obviously pressured by higher raw material costs. And just based on your comments, it looks like that we should -- margin should push higher, directionally, into 4Q and also higher into 1Q. But do you still feel though that as we perhaps look out to the rest of '11 and assuming no new inflation, that 10% operating margin is still the right level of operating margins for that business?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ghansham, this is Dean. Our long-term target hasn't changed. We think that the Pressure-sensitive Materials sector should operate in the 10% to 12% operating margin range. We're not giving guidance for 2011. And -- but I also expect us to catch up on
componenttext: Yes, Ghansham, this is Dean. Our long-term target hasn't changed. We think that the Pressure-sensitive Materials sector should operate in the 10% to 12% operating margin range. We're not giving guidance for 2011. And -- but I also expect us to catch up on some of this inflation in the fourth quarter as our price increases begin to catch up with the additional inflation we're seeing. Correctly, the big question for me is, when will the inflation start to curtail? And we just don't know yet.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you look at trends on PSM for both 2Q and 3Q, did 2Q benefit from some sort of pre-buying ahead of your price increases?
componenttext: Okay. And then as you look at trends on PSM for both 2Q and 3Q, did 2Q benefit from some sort of pre-buying ahead of your price increases?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we rarely see that in this business, especially these days, because customers -- as I talk to customers, they basically are seeing their customers are ordering just as the rate of demand. So everybody's being quite cautious about building inventory. S
componenttext: No, we rarely see that in this business, especially these days, because customers -- as I talk to customers, they basically are seeing their customers are ordering just as the rate of demand. So everybody's being quite cautious about building inventory. So I don't see any changes in customer behavior trying to build inventory in advance of price increases.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one final one on cash flow, just based on Mitch's last comments. Obviously, free cash flow has improved considerably. Your debt positions improved quite a bit as well. Understand that it maybe too early to qualify to sort of think about a d
componenttext: Okay. And just one final one on cash flow, just based on Mitch's last comments. Obviously, free cash flow has improved considerably. Your debt positions improved quite a bit as well. Understand that it maybe too early to qualify to sort of think about a dividend increase just based on the cut last year, but what's the board's appetite on meaningful slug of share buybacks?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the board, and we said this -- I think we said this last quarter and we certainly talk to investors that the board was us to get the year "in the can," in other words, put to bed. We are certainly feeling good about our financial position. And our d
componenttext: Well, the board, and we said this -- I think we said this last quarter and we certainly talk to investors that the board was us to get the year "in the can," in other words, put to bed. We are certainly feeling good about our financial position. And our desire is to return more cash to shareholders. And I am feeling pretty good about -- we'll use a -- both potential dividend increases and share buyback as a way to return more cash to shareholders. That will very likely -- that will very likely happen in 2011.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: This is Silke Kueck for Jeff. A couple of questions. In RIS, it seems that if I remember the trends correctly, it seems that July was sort of more sluggish and August, too, and then September really picked up. And are the indications now that -- because normally, it's a seasonal step up from the third quarter to fourth quarter that the fourth quarter could be really large, or is that the case that there was some forward selling in September from the fourth quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a complex question to answer, but I'll take a crack at it. One of the issues that's been happening in the supply chain for apparel this year is that there's been a pretty large bottleneck of getting goods out of South China for a number of reasons.
componenttext: That's a complex question to answer, but I'll take a crack at it. One of the issues that's been happening in the supply chain for apparel this year is that there's been a pretty large bottleneck of getting goods out of South China for a number of reasons. And so the seasonality this year has been changed a bit. So the third quarter, I think, came in a little stronger because of goods coming in late that normally would have come in the second quarter. I will say that the order trends early in the fourth quarter and late in the third quarter have continued to be positive for us. And I attribute that to our service levels. We've captured some new programs, and the fact that the inventory-to-sales ratio in apparel is still relatively low. So I still remain cautiously optimistic about the business going forward.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But we don't expect necessarily the high teens to be the trend going into Q4 for year-over-year growth for the reasons of the shift in timing of the counterization a little bit this year because of the bottlenecks being talked about.
componenttext: But we don't expect necessarily the high teens to be the trend going into Q4 for year-over-year growth for the reasons of the shift in timing of the counterization a little bit this year because of the bottlenecks being talked about.

componenttext: I think it's hard to predict actually. It's hard to predict and we don't want to get into specific segment expectations overall for the quarter. But overall, you would expect Q2 to be the strongest within this business, and fourth quarter is the second strongest, followed by the third and then the first quarters. You would not expect, I would say for the reasons Dean commented on, the third quarter did not drop off as much as normal and we would -- so therefore, we wouldn't expect the fourth quarter to bounce back quite as strong.

componenttext: Okay. I'm sorry. Okay, that makes it clear. In terms of raw materials, are the pressures that you have seen due to some shortages maybe in acrylics, can you mitigate this somehow by purchasing globally? And do you expect the tightness to continue, or will it was sort of like moderate into next year? And Maybe you can comment like whether you have the opportunities to purchase more regionally.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we do purchase globally. And I think our team has done a terrific job at making sure we stayed in supply. In fact, in -- and some of the reason that it costs us a little money is that we went out on the spot market a bit early and made sure we had s
componenttext: Well, we do purchase globally. And I think our team has done a terrific job at making sure we stayed in supply. In fact, in -- and some of the reason that it costs us a little money is that we went out on the spot market a bit early and made sure we had sources of supply. A couple of our competitors have had put certain products on sales allocation for a while due to the shortages. But we did not have to do that. We didn't expect to see any deflation in the back half of the year from acrylic monomers, although the industry talk was, and what we've actually seen, is an acceleration of cost increases, rather than the other way. So I think until the total supply-demand situation gets in better balance, it's going to be continuing to be tight. But we've got -- and I think our team has done a good job of global sourcing to make sure that we have a secure supply sources for adhesive.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just related to that, how much price have you achieved today than pressure sensitive? And what are you looking for in the fourth quarter? Or what's the price increase that you're going out with?
componenttext: And just related to that, how much price have you achieved today than pressure sensitive? And what are you looking for in the fourth quarter? Or what's the price increase that you're going out with?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, for example -- let me answer the amount, and then Mitch will comment on how much price we have achieved. We have announced a mid to high single-digit price increase in North America. And also in China, we've announced an increase in the mid-single d
componenttext: Well, for example -- let me answer the amount, and then Mitch will comment on how much price we have achieved. We have announced a mid to high single-digit price increase in North America. And also in China, we've announced an increase in the mid-single digit range as well. And I know we're looking at this in other regions. As you might guess, given the U.S. dollar, the inflation tends to be more intense in dollar-denominated countries. So it's a pretty substantial price increase, but we need it. Our margins are really taking a hit because of the adhesive costs.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So overall, as far as the level of price increases, we are behind the curve. And given that, that curve keeps accelerating on the raw material inflation, we keep adding -- do more price increases, but continue to behind that curve. I mean, we don't expect
componenttext: So overall, as far as the level of price increases, we are behind the curve. And given that, that curve keeps accelerating on the raw material inflation, we keep adding -- do more price increases, but continue to behind that curve. I mean, we don't expect to close it until early next year. If you ask within PSM the amount for the price increases, it depends on what your starting point is overall. But we've recovered less than half, about 1/3 of the total inflation that we've seen in the third quarter relative to third quarter of last year within PSM.  And now we're facing an additional $10 million of incremental inflation in the fourth quarter, which we didn't see when we spoke with you 3 months ago, which we want everybody to remember. Silke, you mentioned the seasonality in RIS, and that could be less -- more muted this year than in a normal year. But I think it's also important to remember the seasonality in Office Products. And the seasonality on Office Products would likely be magnified in a situation this year because BTS doesn't have a lot of the areas where we're experiencing the increased competition. And that could impact Office Products more in the fourth quarter as well.

componenttext: So we're coming at the low end for the reason you've stated. It's more of the spend is actually just sliding into 2011. But you -- we won't provide specific guidance for 2011, but you would expect capital expenditures to increase next year versus where they are this year. And one of the other reasons for that other than just the timing of the ramp-up curve is RFID. So we do expect increased capital expenditures for RFID next year relative to what we have this year.

componenttext: Okay. And then secondly, if raw material costs stayed just where they are right now or at least where your expectations, are you expecting some additional rise here in the current quarter? Do you have a -- would 2011 over 2010 kind of be half of that $105 million or so because half of the increase here has occurred in the second half of the year? I don't know if the things were going -- actually, things have accelerated. So it might -- you might think that 2011 might be up over 2010 by more than half of the 2010 over 2009 change?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It really accelerated between the second quarter and the third quarter. And well, we're still seeing more in the fourth quarter. But as you can see, it's $10 million incremental from what we've previously thought. So it's at roughly half. I don't have the
componenttext: It really accelerated between the second quarter and the third quarter. And well, we're still seeing more in the fourth quarter. But as you can see, it's $10 million incremental from what we've previously thought. So it's at roughly half. I don't have the specifics in front of me, but it's roughly half you could expect carryover, mostly in the first half of the year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm curious on your comments of RFID tracking sales having doubled. Can you remind us where you're tracking on an annualized run rate basis? And I guess, related to this so I can -- I hope you make this one question, what is the mood of your retail custom
componenttext: I'm curious on your comments of RFID tracking sales having doubled. Can you remind us where you're tracking on an annualized run rate basis? And I guess, related to this so I can -- I hope you make this one question, what is the mood of your retail customers in terms of their willingness to spend the capital needed to enable them to more aggressively use your tags?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the $15 million charges in total external sales for us in RFID-related items, we're still on track for that. We signed an additional agreement in the last quarter with a major retailer, who is implementing item-level tagging. Unfortunately, I can'
componenttext: Yes. So the $15 million charges in total external sales for us in RFID-related items, we're still on track for that. We signed an additional agreement in the last quarter with a major retailer, who is implementing item-level tagging. Unfortunately, I can't say who they are. But there is an increasing appetite for implementing these programs across the industry. So the capital expense, frankly, isn't huge for a lot of these retailers, I mean, compared to what they're spending their money on today. So I consider it to be a real positive trend. The one point I want to make though is that the sales increases and the profit increases we're getting in RIS are barely impacted by current RFID item level. So we still have a lot of traction left in that business without RFID. And for me, RFID is really icing on the cake, and so it remains a good medium- to long-term upside for this business. But it's tracking along really well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if it's not much, capital on the customers' behalf, what is the pushback, if any, on why they're not embracing it more aggressively?
componenttext: And if it's not much, capital on the customers' behalf, what is the pushback, if any, on why they're not embracing it more aggressively?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's really, there's 2 things. One is the changed management process. You have to change the way your process has worked at a store and in your supply chain. And if you have 1,800 stores, that takes time to do. And the second thing is, of course, the incr
componenttext: It's really, there's 2 things. One is the changed management process. You have to change the way your process has worked at a store and in your supply chain. And if you have 1,800 stores, that takes time to do. And the second thing is, of course, the increase in consumables costs. So the price that could go is from $0.01 to $0.02 to $0.10 to $0.12. So -- and that's an ongoing cost. There is clearly a payback and the benefit for that activity. But most retailers like to test the concept out in a number of product lines or a number of stores to gain confidence that they can execute, and then they tend to roll out.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a tax planning event that's occurring in a non-U.S. jurisdiction, and it's essentially coming in the form of a net operating loss as a result of some of the legal entity and restructuring that we've done throughout the year. And so that's being
componenttext: Sure. It's a tax planning event that's occurring in a non-U.S. jurisdiction, and it's essentially coming in the form of a net operating loss as a result of some of the legal entity and restructuring that we've done throughout the year. And so that's being triggered in the fourth quarter, and we'll recognize the benefit. It's non-cash this year, and we're expecting to get the cash benefit in a few years' time.
